headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Legg Mason Third Fiscal Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this teleconference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Magleby, Head of Investor Relations and Corporate Commu
componenttext:
Welcome to the Legg Mason Third Fiscal Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this teleconference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Magleby, Head of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Thank you, Mr. Maccabee. You may begin.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2015 third quarter ended December 31, 2014.This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of
componenttext:
Thank you. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2015 third quarter ended December 31, 2014.
This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not statements of facts or guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed in the statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see risk factors and management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, and in the company's subsequent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
During the call today, we may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the non-GAAP financial measures to the comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the press release that we issued this morning, which is available in the Investor Relations section of our website. The company undertakes no obligation to update the information contained in this presentation to reflect subsequently occurring events or circumstances.
This morning's call will include remarks from Mr. Joe Sullivan, Legg Mason's Chairman and CEO; and Mr. Pete Nachtwey, Legg Mason's CFO, who will discuss our financial results. In addition, following a review of the company's quarter, we will then open the call to Q&A.
Now I would like to turn this call over to Mr. Joe Sullivan. Joe?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everyone. As always, I appreciate your interest in Legg Mason and welcome you to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Call.We are pleased to announce another quarter of financial and strategic momentum. As we enter t
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan, and good morning, everyone. As always, I appreciate your interest in Legg Mason and welcome you to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Call.
We are pleased to announce another quarter of financial and strategic momentum. As we enter this new calendar year, we intend to build on our progress and capitalize on the investment performance by our affiliates, which remained strong on a broad set of strategies and products. We enjoy a diverse lineup of high-performing investment offerings to address a global marketplace that's well characterized by dramatic differences across many economies, are nevertheless very interconnected and share similar investment challenges. Global events impacting investors range from a very turbulent geopolitical environment to volatility in the currency and energy markets, and certainly, persistently low interest rates, which have created a bit of a desperation for yield across the globe. But it is precisely this volatility that our active managers believes offers significant opportunity for long-term investors to achieve substantial returns. 
This morning, Pete will take you through the quarter from a financial performance standpoint, while I'd like to focus you on what I believe to be the 5 key takeaways for Legg Mason today.
First, and most importantly, the investment performance that we've delivered for clients remain strong overall. 
Second, we've made significant progress in expanding and evolving our product lineup to address the real and changing needs of global investors, though we are still in the very early innings of commercializing the opportunities that we have acquired through QS and Martin Currie. 
Third, we have made substantial progress with respect to the chronic net flow challenges, and we're very pleased to have been in positive long-term net flows for 3 consecutive quarters.
Fourth, we have maintained significant financial strength and flexibility through strategic debt refinancings, while we continue to generate and retain a significant amount of cash. 
And finally, we remain committed to investing in our business where and when we see opportunity, while growing our dividend and remaining committed to share repurchases. These are the 5 key themes that I hope you keep in mind as I walk you through some of the highlights.
Slide 2 presents the highlights for the quarter. Net income was $77 million or $0.67 per diluted share. Assets under management rose to $709 billion. We achieved $8.8 billion of long-term inflows, driven by nearly $10 billion in fixed income, offset by approximately $1 billion in equity outflows.
Fixed income inflows are particularly notable as the mutual fund industry actually experienced outflows in U.S. taxable fixed income for the quarter. While there is both art and science to the analysis, we believe that approximately 2/3 of our fixed income inflow was impacted by the money in motion underway in this space. That said, and I want to be very clear about this: Even absent the recent manager transition, we have been achieving solid net inflows and gaining market share, in particular, with our unconstrained and absolute return products, which offer the potential for our active managers to deliver value, especially in a more challenging market environment.
We recorded the second consecutive quarter of record global distribution growth and net sales across the entire platform. And as I mentioned earlier, our investment performance remains strong broadly, with 75% or more of strategy AUM exceeding benchmarks for all relevant time periods.
We ended the quarter with an aggregate $8.7 billion in unfunded wins, up from $6.3 billion at the end of September. We closed the acquisition of Martin Currie and the sale of LMIC during the quarter and we repurchased 1.6 million shares year.
And finally, our Board of Directors has approved an additional $1 billion share repurchase authorization, which we intend to deploy once we exhaust our current authorization.
Slide 3 is a very important slide. It shows AUM by affiliate in order of their earnings contribution to Legg Mason, and assets under management by asset class, by client type and by geography. This slide reinforces the increasing diversification of our business, a fact that I believe continues to be underappreciated. 
We see significant opportunity in our retail business, not only with our existing strategies and legacy affiliates, but as we bring Martin Currie's strategies into retail structures and implement sales campaigns around new products launched with QS investors. As I said earlier, these are initiatives that will take time, but they are part of a broader plan that will position Legg Mason for sustained and dependable growth going forward. I am quite pleased with the progress we've made in integrating those firms into Legg Mason, and we are solidly on track with bringing QS and Martin Currie to the global retail marketplace.
Slide 4 provides a snapshot of each of our core affiliates. Brandywine Global had $2.3 billion in total inflows, led by $1.6 billion in fixed income and $700 million in equities. Brandywine's pipeline remains strong at $2.1 billion. And for the second time in 3 years, Steve Smith, David Hoffman, and Jack Macentire, were nominated for the 2014 Morningstar U.S. Fixed Income Fund Manager of the Year for the Legg Mason Brandywine Global opportunities funds. Brandywine also won 2 awards from Asia Asset Management magazine, further recognition of their continued strong investment performance in global bond portfolios. 
ClearBridge Investments had $2.7 billion in inflows, its eighth straight quarter of positive net flows. This is a very, very strong showing, contrasting with the U.S. active equity mutual fund industry, which has been in outflows since March of 2014. Unfunded wins at Clearbridge stand at $700 million. And while we are pleased that Clearbridge has a category killer product and Aggressive Growth, their institutional wins and pipeline reflect investor interest in a broader set of strategies, including international value and large-cap growth. Those products as well as the Clearbridge tactical dividend and income products are also beginning to see good interest from our retail client base.
Martin Currie had $400 million outflows for the quarter, a portion of which we have previously disclosed as related to the transaction. Martin Currie closed the quarter with $1.1 billion in unfunded wins. The integration of Martin Currie with Legg Mason Australia has been completed and the firm has now been rebranded Martin Currie Australia. We have signed distribution agreements, enabling our global distribution teams to sell existing Martin Currie funds in the U.K, Europe, Asia and Latin America. And as I've said, we are in the process of bringing the remaining products to the global retail marketplace.
Permal had $20 million outflows for the quarter. The transition underway at Permal from the European high net worth sector to the institutional channel continues, and we are working with them to expand their presence in both the U.S. and international retail markets through the launch of liquid alternatives products.
QS Investors experienced $1.2 billion in outflows for the quarter, with $200 million in unfunded wins. The outflows at QS reflect a combination of a few deal-related outflows as well as a single large outflow from a client, whose asset allocation team made a move to passive. At the same time, I'm especially pleased that QS is experiencing momentum in global distribution, particularly with a number of platform wins in the insurance and sub-advisory channels, where we are well positioned to capture flows over time. 
Royce & Associates saw $2.5 billion in outflows during the quarter. As I've said before, we expect this trend to persist for some time as it will take time for their investment performance to recover. We remain very supportive of the work underway at Royce with respect to both investment performance and strengthening their organization for future growth.
And finally, Western Asset Management, with $8.2 billion in long-term inflows, $10.6 billion and liquidity outflows and $4.5 billion in unfunded wins. Western enjoyed strong flows in broad market portfolios, aided by the money in motion phenomena that we've highlighted as well as continued growth in their high-performing unconstrained strategies.
We continue to believe that money in motion in the institutional market is a long-term story extending out 2 [ph] years or more. We are extremely proud that Ken Leech, Karl Eisenstadt and Mark Lindbloom were named Morningstar's U.S. Fixed Income Fund Managers of the Year for the core and core plus funds, and we believe this is well-deserved acknowledgment that will only help grow our business with our retail and intermediary clients.
Now let me take a moment to step back and address fixed income more broadly, and Slide 5 underscores the opportunity before us. As you can see, we have very strong investment performance and capabilities across the fixed income spectrum, and I want to reiterate some of the points that I made on the last earnings call. 
First, this is no time to be passive with respect to fixed income investing. Different investors, depending on their individual objectives, need a variety of fixed income capabilities that perform well in an increasingly complex and volatile macro environment. This has never been more true than today, with extraordinarily low interest rates, volatile currency markets and the changing landscape and sovereign and corporate credit quality. When unconstrained, proven managers in fixed income can modify duration and diversify or otherwise hedge various exposures to avoid the impact that slavishly following a benchmark can have. We have confidence in the capabilities, the resources and the expertise of our fixed income managers as well as a track record of investment performance to capitalize for investors on just such opportunities. 
Now let's look at Slide 6 and talk about our global retail distribution platform. We enjoyed another very strong quarter in global distribution, with the highest levels of growth and net sales in its history. This was the fifth consecutive quarter of positive net sales for the platform, with positive sales in both the U.S. and internationally over that same timeframe. Looking specifically at fixed income, global sales in the taxable fixed income were $13 billion for the quarter, with $6 billion in net sales across mutual funds, retail SMAs and insurance and sub-advise mandates. 
While we believe the opportunity in fixed income is substantial and ongoing, we also achieved positive net sales within global distribution for all of our affiliates, with the exception of Royce. The quarterly redemption rate for our retail platform was 26%, with the quarterly increase driven primarily by 1 sub-advisory mandate redemption in Japan related to interest rates and currencies, and to a lesser degree, an uptick in outflows at Royce. The U.S. redemption rate remained at 20%, well below industry levels.
I'm very pleased that increasingly, our product development efforts reflect collaborative efforts with our global distribution partners. Specifically during the quarter, we enhanced and repositioned products with QS Investors, including the new 401(k) roadmap CIT funds and an innovative retirement solution launched with LPL Financial. Additionally, we launched the Permal alternative select variable insurance trust with MetLife's investment-only variable annuity. It's the collaborative product development and launches such as these that suggest strong long-term growth opportunities in those channels.
And finally, Slide 7 depicts our overall investment performance, which broadly remains strong. 75% or more of our strategy AUM beat benchmarks across all relevant time periods, and 60% or more of our long-term U.S. fund assets beat the Lipper category average over all-time periods. 
And with that, let me turn it over to Pete. Pete?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Turning to Slide 8, I'll start with the financial highlights. As Joe noted, we delivered another solid quarter of operating earnings, with net income of $77 million or $0.67 per diluted share. During the quarter, we incurred our remaining QS-
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Turning to Slide 8, I'll start with the financial highlights. As Joe noted, we delivered another solid quarter of operating earnings, with net income of $77 million or $0.67 per diluted share. During the quarter, we incurred our remaining QS-related integration cost, Martin Currie and LMIC deal-related costs as well as an incremental $3 million of investments in global distribution.
In addition, with the second consecutive quarter of record gross and net sales from our global distribution platform, we saw an increase in sales commission expense. Our revenues increased primarily due to higher performance these as well as the addition of Martin Currie's revenues beginning on October 1st. This was partially offset by the loss of LMIC revenues after their sale on November 7th.
QS integration costs totaled $12.8 million this quarter, while cost related to the Martin Currie acquisition and the sale of LMIC totaled $5.7 million. These were partially offset by a $1.9 million gain on the sale of LMIC, which is included in nonoperating income. Looking forward, we do not anticipate any additional QS integration costs, but we are expecting a further $2.5 million in run rate spending related to our ongoing investments in global distribution. This will bring the run rate cost of these investments in our fiscal fourth quarter and beyond to $7 million to $8 million. 
Adjusted income was $113 million for the quarter or $0.98 per share, which included the impact of QS integration and other M&A-related cost. Average long-term AUM was up 1% from the prior quarter, with average equity up 3% and fixed income basically flat.
This quarter's total performance fees of $29 million were primarily from Brandywine Permal and Western. This quarter's better than forecast performance fees came from Brandywine, where strong performance led to higher than expected performance fee levels. While impossible to predict with any precision, we estimate that next quarter's performance fees could be in the range of $10 million to $15 million. 
On the capital front, this quarter, we repurchased an additional 1.6 million shares. And as Joe mentioned earlier, the Board approved an additional $1 billion repurchase authorization. We intend to deploy this new authorization after our current one is completed, and at our $90 [ph] million historical pace, as always, subject to markets and/or investments and growth opportunities. 
Moving on to Slide 9, the only additional item to highlight here is our GAAP effective tax rate of 32%, which largely reflects the successful completion of prior year's audits, which resulted in the release of tax reserves that increased our earnings per share by $0.03 this quarter. That said, we still expect our effective GAAP tax rate for the full fiscal year to be 35% to 37%. And as we've consistently highlighted, our actual cash tax rate continues to run at a substantially lower level than our GAAP rate. Specifically for this quarter and for the fiscal year, we expect the cash tax rate in the 6% range as you can see on Page 20 in the appendix.
Turning to Slide 10. Our assets under management were up slightly compared to the prior quarter, driven by long-term inflows of $8.8 billion as well as $3.1 billion favorable market impact, and despite $6.4 billion of unfavorable FX impact. AUM related to our acquisition of Martin Currie was offset by the AUM related to the sale of LMIC. 
Also at the bottom of this slide, we note our $116 billion of assets under advisement or AUA, which includes assets across most of our key affiliates. But as a reminder, these are generally very low fee mandates and can occasionally move in a fairly lumpy fashion. So in that spirit, I also want to point out that we're expecting our AUA to decline in February by approximately $80 billion. This is primarily due to a QS client deciding to take this service in-house. Although QS continues to have a very good and sizable AUM relationship with this client, due to its very low fee nature, the annualized impact of this loss is only roughly $0.02 per diluted share.
Long-term flows on Slide 11 were positive $8.8 billion and represent our third quarter of positive long-term inflows. Fixed income inflows of $9.9 billion reflected continued strong performance, combined with high market demand across a variety of our strategies and products. and both our fixed income affiliates, benefited from the money in motion that continues to be underway in fixed income.
Equity flows turned negative, with small cap being our most challenged area, while U.S. large-cap and income-oriented products continue turning in strong performance. 
Slide 12 shows the advisory fee trend with this quarter's lower rate, primarily reflecting the decline in average AUM at Royce. 
Now I'd like a step back for a minute and talk about how this connects to our revenues. Since we've noted over the last few quarters, when you look at net revenues, which is operating revenues less DNS expenses, we seem to be right in line with external estimates. But external expectations around gross operating revenues have continued to run a bit high. On a go-forward basis, using the current quarter's advisory fee rate is a good starting point. With DNS expenses as a percentage of operating revenues typically running between 21% and 22% after excluding performance fees, which will be a good proxy for that line item. So bottom line, we're just trying to get external estimates to our top line more in line with how we see our actual experience. 
Operating expenses on Slide 13 increased by $26 million or 5% to $600 million. I will discuss comp and benefits on the next slide, but looking at the other line items, DNS expense decreased as last quarter's expense included the impact of the Western closed-end fund launch. Occupancy expense increased $11 million, primarily related to the QS integration lease charge as well as from the impact of a prior quarter's lease reserve credit.
Communications and technology expenses increased $3 million due to Martin Currie expenses and the continued investment in global distribution. Other expenses increased $4 million due to Martin Currie, offset by the loss of a personal quarter of LMIC and also reflecting additional investments in global distribution.
Turning to Slide 14. Company benefits increased by $16 million. The increase was primarily due to higher performance fees and higher global distribution sales commissions. The addition of Martin Currie's expenses were partially offset by the reduction from LMIC. Transition cost and severance were also up due to the LMIC sale, while mark-to-market on deferred comp and seed also increased quarter-over-quarter. Compensation and benefits ratio, excluding the LMIC charges and the mark-to-market on deferred comp and seed investment, came in at 54%, consistent with our outlook for 53% to 54% ratio going forward. Next quarter's ration will likely be a bit higher due to seasonal compensation cost. 
Slide 15 highlights the operating margin as adjusted, which decreased to 21.4% from last quarter's 23.8%. The lower margin was primarily due to the increase in QS integration costs as well as the cost related to M&A activity in the quarter. This quarter's operating margin was reduced by 3.3% as a result of those costs, while the prior quarter's operating margin was similarly reduced by 2%. We would expect the operating margin as adjusted to increase next quarter due to the absence of integration cost and M&A activity, but that increase will be partially offset by the increase in seasonal compensation cost, the incremental investments in global distribution as well as lower estimated performance fees.
Slide 16 is a roll forward from fiscal Q2's GAAP earnings per share of $0.04 to this quarter's $0.67 per share. Fiscal Q2 included the debt refinancing and QS Investors' integration as well as other corporate initiative costs of approximately $119 million, which combined to reduce earnings per share by $0.65. 
In fiscal Q3, increases in operating income as well as the impact of share repurchases increased earnings per share by a penny. Mark-to-market on seed investments were positive this quarter compared with negative marks last quarter, and together, with lower interest expense resulting from our refinancing of fiscal Q2, these collectively increased EPS by $0.03. 
And finally, a combination of QS integration, the net cost of the LMIC disposition, Martin Currie acquisition cost, all partially offset by a reduction in tax reserves, reduced earnings by a net $0.06 per share.
I'll wrap up on Slide 17, which highlights our quarterly cash position as well as our consistent and balanced approach to capital deployment. In the upper left, you can see that we have steadily reduced our share count by 50 million shares or 31% since March of 2010. In the upper right, we've highlighted the change in our quarterly dividend over that same timeframe. We now have 5 straight years of increased annual dividends, representing over a fourfold increase since 2010. On the bottom left, you can see our cash position, which stands at $665 million as of December 31, up slightly from September despite the acquisition of Martin Currie in fiscal Q3.
Finally on the bottom right, we highlight our current seed investments of $374 million across a diversified portfolio by asset class. 
In summary, this was a solid quarter for Legg Mason. And as always, we have complemented our growth with a capital deployment strategy that highlights consistent dividends and share repurchases along with significant investments in growth initiatives, both organically and through acquisitions. So thanks for your time and your interest in Legg Mason. And I will turn it back to Joe.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. Building momentum and positioning Legg Mason for growth have been our themes for this fiscal year, and I think it's quite clear that we're making good progress on both. Continued growth in global distribution gross and net sales reflect a
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. Building momentum and positioning Legg Mason for growth have been our themes for this fiscal year, and I think it's quite clear that we're making good progress on both. Continued growth in global distribution gross and net sales reflect a strong lineup of highly-competitive products and strong sales execution. With nearly 90% of the hiring associated with our distribution growth plans complete, we will expand client coverage by approximately 50%, which will be a key driver of future growth and progress.
We are excited about the expanded set of capabilities that we've acquired in QS and Martin Currie. There remains a significant opportunity within fixed income for active global managers, and with our deep expertise, scale, a strong breadth of products and compelling investment performance, we are well positioned to gain market share and grow. We also enjoy broad capabilities and strong investment performance across many of our equity products, and see opportunities to continue to win in active equities across the globe.
As I said upfront, even as we continue to invest in organic growth and M&A, we will continue to actively return capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
And with that, we are happy to take your questions.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015

componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the extra disclosure and your supplement as well. Joe, just -- if you could do the math, $1 billion on your current market cap is about 15%, 16%, just curious, and Pete mentioned to sort of keep that $90 [ph] million pace going. Any const
componenttext: I appreciate all the extra disclosure and your supplement as well. Joe, just -- if you could do the math, $1 billion on your current market cap is about 15%, 16%, just curious, and Pete mentioned to sort of keep that $90 [ph] million pace going. Any constraints here in terms of denominator on the share count? Obviously, we know the news with Mr. Phelps [ph] but just from your perspective on anything that would detract from that ratable return of cash?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, no, we don't see anything. Our discussion with our Board this past week was that we continue to see our shares as undervalued. And as long as we do, we'll continue the buy back at that same pace. Pete, any adds?
componenttext: Bill, no, we don't see anything. Our discussion with our Board this past week was that we continue to see our shares as undervalued. And as long as we do, we'll continue the buy back at that same pace. Pete, any adds?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill. The only constraint as we always have said is around markets or other investment opportunities. So we saw something that had a higher IRR, we believe to the long-term shareholder, that would be the only reason we'd be slowing this down at this
componenttext: Yes, Bill. The only constraint as we always have said is around markets or other investment opportunities. So we saw something that had a higher IRR, we believe to the long-term shareholder, that would be the only reason we'd be slowing this down at this stage. And as you can see, we've been pretty consistent over the last 2 years of that $90 million a quarter.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015

componenttext: Right.  Maybe a 2-part question is my follow up. Part 1 is could you talk about just the implications of passive encroachment relative to the value proposition of QS? And on the other side, how quickly can you add or push some products of Martin Currie to the incremental platforms?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Bill, I think you're getting 3 questions in there.
componenttext: So Bill, I think you're getting 3 questions in there.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: But that's all right, we still love you. As it relates to the implications of passive to QS, I don't think it's any more or less than any of our affiliates. I think it's all about performance over time. Now in the case of QS, I mean, this was not performa
componenttext: But that's all right, we still love you. As it relates to the implications of passive to QS, I don't think it's any more or less than any of our affiliates. I think it's all about performance over time. Now in the case of QS, I mean, this was not performance related. It was really just a move and an allocation move on the part of the client to passive. But I see, actually, there are opportunities growing. As I mentioned, we've seen significant uptake from our global distribution platform, particularly with respect to the insurance sub-advised space. We got on 6 different platforms this past quarter. We've mentioned LPL, we got on Prudential, Transamerica, Lincoln National, MPH. We are making great progress and there's a good uptake. We also have positive net flows in our retail distribution platform for QS. So I'm not particularly concerned or any more concerned about the passive threat to QS than I am about anyone else. As it relates to Martin Currie, this just takes time and it's a grinding kind of a thing. We have to get it -- we're working to get Martin Currie into the U.S. space and for the vehicles as well as use its vehicles, obviously, across the pond. It might be 6 or 9 months candidly before we get them in. It just takes time and we've got to be patient with it, but what I would tell you is we're firing on all cylinders. Our product teams are all over Martin Currie, maybe overwhelming them a little bit, but all over them in terms of getting their strategies into vehicles that we can sell in the retail market space

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Bill, one thing I'd add to that is we're seeing some unintended revenue synergies actually from Martin Currie. As Joe mentioned in his remarks, we've combined our former Legg Mason Australian equity business into Martin Currie. They've got some league
componenttext: And Bill, one thing I'd add to that is we're seeing some unintended revenue synergies actually from Martin Currie. As Joe mentioned in his remarks, we've combined our former Legg Mason Australian equity business into Martin Currie. They've got some league-leading products in Australia and Martin Currie's institutional sales folks in Asia have been very aggressive at getting them introduced to the clients and we're seeing some traction there. So again, that's something we've modeled into the deal, but an unintended benefit that we're definitely seeing.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question exquisite is from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question relates to your margin. If we add some of the QS and Martin Currie cost, I think you guys were at 24.7% this quarter. The last quarter it looks like 25.8% on a like basis. So I know there's a lot of moving parts, but anyway, you guys could
componenttext: First question relates to your margin. If we add some of the QS and Martin Currie cost, I think you guys were at 24.7% this quarter. The last quarter it looks like 25.8% on a like basis. So I know there's a lot of moving parts, but anyway, you guys could just summarize for us why there is a slight quarter-on-quarter decline there?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, sure, good question. And as we've said in the past, there's a number of kind of key factors that are moving around in our margin all the time, and we refer to it as mix that matter. So there is really 4 [ph] of the key mixed things, which affiliates i
componenttext: No, sure, good question. And as we've said in the past, there's a number of kind of key factors that are moving around in our margin all the time, and we refer to it as mix that matter. So there is really 4 [ph] of the key mixed things, which affiliates is the revenue and growth coming from what asset classes, what client types and what geographies, because they all have different impacts in our margins. So none of them move in the same direction. They all move, but rarely do they ever move in the same direction. Well, we also had some, I think, key factors in this quarter, most of which are going to turn around and be positive going forward. But the first is just our continued investment in LMGD. and as we've talked about, we see great opportunity from expanding our coverage and doing some additional things on the technology side there. We've made investments in the past, really going back to when Joe was running at a couple of years ago. And those have taken a bit of time to pay off, but that's what you're seeing pay off now in higher sales, and we're very confident that we're going to get higher sales, net sales, from the investments we're making today. The other thing we're seeing is because of the record sales -- keep in mind, we have a lot of front-end loaded cost in our sales commission structure whenever we sell products to the retail channel. So we had a couple of million dollars of incremental commissions this quarter because of record sales, so that's a good thing, particularly given the fact that we'll have those assets for 4 to 5 years and no additional commission coming from that. And then a couple of other factors, the swap of Martin Currie coming in at a lower margin than LMIC. But we have the ability and are seeing it to grow Martin Currie that we didn't have with LMIC, so a much stronger platform. And then minor impact from FX, we're pretty well naturally hedged there, but not perfectly. I know that's 1 -- that's been on people's minds in terms of currency impact, had a slight impact on us, not that much. So bottom line, we're very confident we can improve the margin from here by controlling costs. And as you can see, we've been doing that consistently over the last 2 to 3 years. But more importantly, growing revenues. And the product gaps that we filled already with these acquisitions, the next generation products that Tom Hoops and his team are pumping out, and the payback that we are already seeing from prior year investments in LMGD, we're very confident and bullish on the payback opportunity from these current investments.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Real quick follow-up. On the pipeline, you guys mentioned being a record, great things happening there. Any comments on how close you're trending so far in January?
componenttext: Real quick follow-up. On the pipeline, you guys mentioned being a record, great things happening there. Any comments on how close you're trending so far in January?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, as you well know, ours is a pretty large, diverse and global business. And so as a result of that, it does take several days after the close of the quarter to confirm, to reconcile the numbers across affiliates, come across products and across geog
componenttext: Chris, as you well know, ours is a pretty large, diverse and global business. And so as a result of that, it does take several days after the close of the quarter to confirm, to reconcile the numbers across affiliates, come across products and across geographies. But that said, this is the last day of the month, so we do have some pretty good visibility into our flows, and I would say that I'm pleased with what appears to be shaping up as another strong month.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Robert Lee from KBW.
componenttext: Our next question is from Robert Lee from KBW.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm just curious. Maybe looking at Permal, I know that, I guess, a little bit of doubt for this quarter. Maybe it was last quarter, you had a little bit of inflow, but could you break down for us now how that movement of that business has changed, what th
componenttext: I'm just curious. Maybe looking at Permal, I know that, I guess, a little bit of doubt for this quarter. Maybe it was last quarter, you had a little bit of inflow, but could you break down for us now how that movement of that business has changed, what the current institutional high networks split is? And maybe some detail, some color around the flows in those relative segments?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. You may recall, because I think you've been covering us for quite a while. When we acquired Permal in 2005, December of 2005, that business was almost exclusively a European high net worth business. And going through the crisis and following the cri
componenttext: Sure. You may recall, because I think you've been covering us for quite a while. When we acquired Permal in 2005, December of 2005, that business was almost exclusively a European high net worth business. And going through the crisis and following the crisis, for Permal and really for the industry, that business has been in decline, and frankly, in attrition. And I would argue that Permal has really done a remarkable job in transforming their business from what was just over 0% -- I've kind of made the comment, but I think they had 1 institutional client when we acquired them and after the acquisition we had 0. Today, that business is roughly 70% institutional. Now when I talk about it transitioning in that European high net worth business, in attrition, I think that is a broad industry trend. But it doesn't mean that there's not opportunities on the retail side. And what we're doing with Permal, we have launched in the U.S. a liquid alternatives strategy that we're excited about. I think I mentioned the launch of a product in the MetLife system this past quarter. We have launched other kind of liquid alternative type products in the U.S. and we're close, I think in the next quarter, this quarter or next, should have a usage vehicle for Permal to be able to address the retail space in Europe and other places. So again, they've really transitioned their business dramatically from basically an entirely retail business to an institutional business, but there is opportunity in the retail side that we think we can capture over time.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe as my follow-up, and shifting to Western. You reference kind of the money in motion in the marketplace, and some of the -- Western has been a beneficiary. But part of that money in motion is in the, I believe, in the kind of the DCIO chann
componenttext: Okay. And maybe as my follow-up, and shifting to Western. You reference kind of the money in motion in the marketplace, and some of the -- Western has been a beneficiary. But part of that money in motion is in the, I believe, in the kind of the DCIO channel. So can you talk a little bit about if you're starting to see some wins there? Or do you think that's kind of one of the -- that takes longer to move, so do you think you will see that -- that's one of the things that will help drive flows for you guys over the next year or so in the DC channel?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think the short answer to that is yes. We are seeing some business there and we expect to see some additional business there. But as I mentioned in my comments, evaluating how much of our flows are related to money in motion versus what were good,
componenttext: Sure. I think the short answer to that is yes. We are seeing some business there and we expect to see some additional business there. But as I mentioned in my comments, evaluating how much of our flows are related to money in motion versus what were good, strong underlying core growth transfer, both Western and Brandywine, it's a bit of an art and science. What we saw, and the way we sort of experienced, it was we saw immediate moves in the retail space as you would imagine. A number of people moving in with, whether it be in mutual funds, whether it be in SMAs, where we have a very strong presence. I think we're the second-largest provider of SMAs in the industry. We saw a great pickup in SMAs. We very strong pickup in a mutual fund market share over the last 3 months. So that was sort of the immediate uptake. We did see in the insurance sub-advise and some DCIO mandates come in fairly quickly, where they were able to pull the trigger faster in this spaces. We did see some uptake there. I would say that the institutional business that we -- that kind of the traditional consultant-driven institutional business just takes time, and we do believe this is a plus, minus 2-year type of phenomena because you're dealing with consultants. You're dealing with investment committees. You're dealing with Boards that have to go through a much longer process. We think that will be kind of lumpy. We think it will be kind -- it'll ebb and flow a little bit overtime. We are pleased for -- Western, in particular, has seen significant improvement in their consultant rankings and their opportunities based on consultant, so that gives us a good feel about the opportunities before us from that standpoint. So we feel good. One of the things I will tell you is that -- that I think is interesting, and again, this reinforces the underlying momentum of our fixed income business away from the money in motion phenomena. And that is that, from our unfunded wins on a forward-looking basis, from December 31st on, only a very, very small amount of that is actually related to the money in motion. And so the vast majority of that is really the underlying core strength of our fixed income business that we would have seen in any respect.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Max from Gabelli. .
componenttext: Our next question is from Max from Gabelli. .

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats to the team, it's terrific. Just to extend on Bill's question a little bit more probably in general, in terms of global distribution. Can you talk about the sales dynamic with non-U.S. investors into U.S. products? And how do you convince these i
componenttext: Congrats to the team, it's terrific. Just to extend on Bill's question a little bit more probably in general, in terms of global distribution. Can you talk about the sales dynamic with non-U.S. investors into U.S. products? And how do you convince these investors to go with active management in the U.S. to what a pretty lengthy market and also headlines in the broader industry that suggest that active management continue to underperform in general?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think, first of all, we think about passive and active not as an orb in an end. We do acknowledge and recognize that the passive space got a legitimate place in investors' portfolios. Active managers are going to struggle when correlations a
componenttext: Well, look, I think, first of all, we think about passive and active not as an orb in an end. We do acknowledge and recognize that the passive space got a legitimate place in investors' portfolios. Active managers are going to struggle when correlations are low and that's sort of been the case. And so it's always on us as an active manager to prove our worth and to actually deliver alpha in excess of the fees that we charge. So we get that, we understand that. As it relates to our international platform, what we've said for a long time up until our recent acquisition of Martin Currie was that, really, we were working on global fixed income capabilities and global fixed income products, and that we only had U.S. equity capabilities for the most part to be able to offer to the retail investor. Our global fixed income capability, where we're seeing the uptake there, is not really in core and core plus or broad market strategies, but we're seeing a significant ramp in the absolute return and unconstrained strategies. There's a great uptake there as well as the global opportunistic strategies that Brandywine has. So it's a very, very significant part of our business globally, and we see our market share has grown dramatically in U.S. equities and active U.S. equities internationally. And we see overtime, our ability to grow our non-U.S. equity space with the addition of Martin Currie and as well as a few select non-U.S. equity strategies that Clearbridge, for example, or Brandywine.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Mac, I'll just add to that in terms of the macro factors, the U.S. economy is viewed as strengthening kind of across the globe. So we're one of the few strong economies. Europe's kind of flat in its back in the emerging markets, so possibly challenged
componenttext: And Mac, I'll just add to that in terms of the macro factors, the U.S. economy is viewed as strengthening kind of across the globe. So we're one of the few strong economies. Europe's kind of flat in its back in the emerging markets, so possibly challenged with the price of energy. So the U.S. is actually, again, continuing to be a safe haven and a growing one. And then the FX dynamic, because we're taking off much of our QE, our currency is perceived to be stronger. So we get a double dip the investing and a stronger economy and getting the FX pop as an international investor, that's a good thing.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, the other thing is it's pretty simple, right? I mean, it's pretty fundamental with respect to global distribution. Whether it's in the U.S. or international, it's about products and having the right products in the right space. We do right now. It's
componenttext: Matt, the other thing is it's pretty simple, right? I mean, it's pretty fundamental with respect to global distribution. Whether it's in the U.S. or international, it's about products and having the right products in the right space. We do right now. It's about investment performance. Those products that we have are performing well. And then it's about the execution of a distribution strategy, and we're getting that done, both in the U.S. and in international. One last point about this, we evaluated our business across 6 basic regions. Each of our regions year-to-date are in positive net flow. Every -- all 6 of our regions are in positive net flows. And within the global distribution platform, every major affiliate we have, with the exception of Royce, every major affiliate is in positive net flow with our global distribution platform.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Carrier from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Carrier from Bank of America.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Pete, maybe first one for you. Just on the fee rate, when I think about the quarter, there are a lot of moving pieces in terms of markets FX, and then the money market's coming out and the long-term flows being healthy. So when we think about maybe the ne
componenttext: Pete, maybe first one for you. Just on the fee rate, when I think about the quarter, there are a lot of moving pieces in terms of markets FX, and then the money market's coming out and the long-term flows being healthy. So when we think about maybe the near-term and longer-term, given the mix of flows that you're seeing in fixed income, and then longer-term, as you can kind of accelerate the blows with Martin Currie and QS, like, where should our expectations be for the fee rate? Obviously, assuming like a flat market backdrop?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. And what you've seen on that, on the graph where we plotted out the advisory fee rate, is a very, very tiny changes, because they're kind of just 5 digits right at the decimal point. But we're not oblivious to the trend, and I like the way you
componenttext: Yes, Mike. And what you've seen on that, on the graph where we plotted out the advisory fee rate, is a very, very tiny changes, because they're kind of just 5 digits right at the decimal point. But we're not oblivious to the trend, and I like the way you framed it and spoke the near term and then the longer term, or intermediate to longer term. Because right now, what's driving that -- the majority of that is really driven by mix from our 2 highest fee affiliates: Royce, which is higher fee equity and retail assets; and obviously, they're in some outflows, and we expect those to last for a bit. But also, Permal has been a negative contributor. But that's kind of a good news, bad news story. The bad news side, as Joe said, high net worth is kind of moving away from the space, but institutional is coming in, and institutional tends be a bifurcation of fees, so it's still a higher fee than our average products and other areas. But it's lower than what the high net worth guys are paying. Flip side of that is, that also comes with performance fee opportunities, and those really haven't kicked in. So we're modestly bullish around that impact, kind of mitigating itself going forward. But so, these are kind of the negatives. But there's a number of positives that are working through the system, and we're seeing real value from those today. It just hasn't quite yet offset the negative impacts to the other ones. And those include the fact that we're seeing very positive flows out of Clearbridge and Brandywine on their equity products. Secondly, we're doing a number of proactive things that are going to help to address this. Obviously, you've seen the affiliate acquisitions, both Martin Currie, in particular. But even QS that have higher fee products in the blended rate. All of the next-generation products that Tom Hoops and his team are working on and pumping out are generally at higher fee, including 2 liquid-all products that we've just launch in Permal. We're looking at launching a third that will go to the retail space. And then probably most importantly is the strong trend from LMGD, Legg Mason Global Distribution, both in the U.S. but even more importantly, internationally. So those assets also come here. So I'd say there's a chance this thing might get some more, but we're dealing with 1, 1 thousandths of a percent, now it's dipping before it turns out. But we're pretty confident as we look forward in our projections as that starts climbing towards the middle of this calendar year.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a  quick follow up, given the investments that you guys are making on the distribution side, and maybe getting into some of the past ones that you've made, from a time frame, maybe given the mix of products that you hav
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a  quick follow up, given the investments that you guys are making on the distribution side, and maybe getting into some of the past ones that you've made, from a time frame, maybe given the mix of products that you have in this suite now versus what you had in the past, if when you expect to see some of that traction build? I think it's hard because obviously, at $9 billion of inflows in the quarter, it's not like you don't have traction, but that might be more in a way towards -- it will actually more weighted towards fixed income. And so when you are making these investments on the distribution side, when and where can you see that traction over the next couple of quarters or 1 to 2 years?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's is kind of like what you've said Michael I think we could see some modest traction, and I'd say it would be modest in the next 2 quarters. But I think over the next couple of years is when we would see it. We are adding. Our investments
componenttext: Yes. I think it's is kind of like what you've said Michael I think we could see some modest traction, and I'd say it would be modest in the next 2 quarters. But I think over the next couple of years is when we would see it. We are adding. Our investments include people, where we, at the end of the day, are expecting our client-facing capability to be raised -- a number of people that our client's facing to be up by about 50%. We're very close to being completed with the hiring of those resources of those people. I think we're about 90% done with the hiring associated with that. And so ultimately, we would say our client-facing activity will be up 50%. That's only a good thing. And I would say that what is of particular benefit to us today, even versus a few years ago when we were making investments, is the momentum at Legg Mason, the number of products, as I mentioned earlier, that are relevant and that are high-performing kind of give you a chance to ramp that a little bit more quickly. Now the other thing, in addition to investing people or investing in technology and training. And technology and training is an opportunity to accelerate and leverage our existing salesforce. So it's not all about kind of investing in the future, but as we get that -- as our technology investment takes hold, and as our training, which is already underway, investment takes hold, our existing salesforce can be more productive and more effective. So it's kind of a good environment for us for our newer people who are getting out and making new contacts and relationships, the buzz the momentum around Legg Mason will help them and should accelerate the opportunity to get a return on that. And then the technology and training investments will help our existing salesforce that already have those relationships.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Mike, I'll just add, we're not done with the payback from the investments we've made in the prior years. We can continue to see benefits growing from those. So it's not like we're envisioning a pause and then waiting a couple of quarters or year befor
componenttext: And Mike, I'll just add, we're not done with the payback from the investments we've made in the prior years. We can continue to see benefits growing from those. So it's not like we're envisioning a pause and then waiting a couple of quarters or year before the new ones kick in.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Daniel Fannon from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question is from Daniel Fannon from Jefferies.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get your thoughts on after a very active year in terms of adding affiliates and even actually exiting a few, how you're thinking about the product lineup and your affiliate suite today going forward through basically product innovation and/or
componenttext: I wanted to get your thoughts on after a very active year in terms of adding affiliates and even actually exiting a few, how you're thinking about the product lineup and your affiliate suite today going forward through basically product innovation and/or additional M&A?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. We continue to be active in the M&A space. We're not looking, as we've said in the past, to add what we would consider to be overlapping capabilities. We feel like we've had a good part of the landscape covered now. What we're really looking at and
componenttext: Sure. We continue to be active in the M&A space. We're not looking, as we've said in the past, to add what we would consider to be overlapping capabilities. We feel like we've had a good part of the landscape covered now. What we're really looking at and what we're having some success with our -- or activity around, what I would call discrete and sort of incremental investment capability that we think has some traction and has some legs. So we are in discussions. We're very active. I think, candidly, our model increasingly smaller boutiques are seeing our model is very attractive because we've -- we honor the investment independence and operational autonomy concept and then the power of global distribution. I mean, I can't tell you how many firms are contacting us. They'd love for us to kind of sub-advise for them. We're not going to do that. We hold dear this global distribution platform. You kind of have to be part of the team to have access to it. So we're an attractive acquirer right now. We're going to be selective as it relates to either adding incremental discrete, investment capability that we think just adds to our lineup. And there are other things out there that could come into play or upgrading as our affiliates look to upgrade essentially talent or reinforce and strengthen talent and strengthen their succession. We could do lift-outs and things like that. So that's sort of how we think about it.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And then as you think about from here the incremental step up in distribution expense to follow up on the previous question, Pete, you mentioned 2.5%. Is that incremental? Or is it the run -- the expenses have been in there for a wh
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And then as you think about from here the incremental step up in distribution expense to follow up on the previous question, Pete, you mentioned 2.5%. Is that incremental? Or is it the run -- the expenses have been in there for a while in terms of incremental expenses for that. I'm just curious what the step up is? Or if it's just how it compares, I guess, to this past quarter?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we expect another $2.5 million run-rate basis, again, on top of what's already there. And I think as we have been talking since the beginning, the year we started making these investments, with land somewhere in the $7 million to $8 million range
componenttext: Yes. No, we expect another $2.5 million run-rate basis, again, on top of what's already there. And I think as we have been talking since the beginning, the year we started making these investments, with land somewhere in the $7 million to $8 million range per quarter of incremental investments in that business, and that's pretty much where we expect to land by the end of Q4. So $2.5 million more than this past quarter.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Craig Siegenthaler from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question is from Craig Siegenthaler from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, just wanted to touch back on QS. I heard your comments on the driver, there are very small outflows here, but do you expect significant near-term improvement in flows from the QS sub, probably driven by traction insurance in sub-advisory channels?
componenttext: First, just wanted to touch back on QS. I heard your comments on the driver, there are very small outflows here, but do you expect significant near-term improvement in flows from the QS sub, probably driven by traction insurance in sub-advisory channels? And also, is this more of an early innings type of progress here? Or do you think we could see actually kind of real flows coming in the next few quarters?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the short answer is we would see them. We see them with a modest pipeline of their institutional business. We did see an uptake in our retail system, and then the significant increase in platform placements that we had this past quarter will be --
componenttext: I think the short answer is we would see them. We see them with a modest pipeline of their institutional business. We did see an uptake in our retail system, and then the significant increase in platform placements that we had this past quarter will be -- we'll just have to see how quickly that results in flows. But that can be both a short term and long term. We'll just have to wait and see. So I would say that there's the opportunity on their own institutional, their kind of legacy institutional business in the short run as well as continued uptake of our retail sales force. And then the platform wins will ask could be short term, but they could be more longer term, I think.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And just as my follow-up here on global distribution, are there any longer-term trend that are providing a tailwind here in the platform? I'm thinking like the new regulations across Europe, a more open architecture, maybe shift from domestic produ
componenttext: Great. And just as my follow-up here on global distribution, are there any longer-term trend that are providing a tailwind here in the platform? I'm thinking like the new regulations across Europe, a more open architecture, maybe shift from domestic products in areas like Europe to a more global product? And also, do you have the contributions specifically from sales in European cross-border relative to the entire global distribution platform?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will let Pete maybe speak to the numbers. I think the -- we are now seeing a real acceleration in our non-U.S. equity platform. This goes to your latter question. We are certainly more profitable in the U.S. where we're more established. That's clear we
componenttext: I will let Pete maybe speak to the numbers. I think the -- we are now seeing a real acceleration in our non-U.S. equity platform. This goes to your latter question. We are certainly more profitable in the U.S. where we're more established. That's clear we have been investing over the last, frankly, 5, 6, 7 years in international or global distribution. We have a very strong presence in Japan, so we're nicely profitable there. But we've been building out in other regions, particularly in the continent and Latin America. As it relates to the trends, I think it's pretty straightforward. I think it's about having global products and products that serve kind of global needs, diversification, income, things like that. And then those products to perform. We, like everyone else, are subject to dealing with changing in a very diverse regulatory environment, and we'll do that. But we don't see that as a substantial headwind, particularly. We're -- I think it's really great just blocking and tackling, having the products, making sure they have investment performance and getting in front of as many clients as possible. And I think we're doing a good job there, particularly with our growth in the international space.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That said quickly, the profitability, the key way to think about it is the incremental dollar, it's very profitable because we get an extra haircut, just given the complexity of dealing with things overseas. So in the incremental dollars it's pound for po
componenttext: That said quickly, the profitability, the key way to think about it is the incremental dollar, it's very profitable because we get an extra haircut, just given the complexity of dealing with things overseas. So in the incremental dollars it's pound for pound, it's possible, profitable maybe a little bit more so than the U.S. The U.S. is bigger and more established, so today, it's more profitable overall. But incremental dollars coming international are very good for us.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Glenn Schorr from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is from Glenn Schorr from Evercore ISI.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick follow-ups. One, on the fixed income flows in the quarter, I think you mentioned 2/3 was related to the money in motion. I think we look at a lot of the money motion business slug upfront, but there is slug that might be in motion over the cours
componenttext: Two quick follow-ups. One, on the fixed income flows in the quarter, I think you mentioned 2/3 was related to the money in motion. I think we look at a lot of the money motion business slug upfront, but there is slug that might be in motion over the course of a period of year or maybe even longer, but I'm curious how you see, in terms of what you benefit from this quarter, what we should expect over the next couple of quarters? Did we see a big amount of movement upfront, and now the rest will be throughout a much longer period of time?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I do think it will be elongated. I think that's probably a good way to think about it. As I mentioned, our $8.8 billion in unfundeds, very -- or $8.7 billion in unfunded for this quarter, a very small amount of it really is in sort of that money motion. A
componenttext: I do think it will be elongated. I think that's probably a good way to think about it. As I mentioned, our $8.8 billion in unfundeds, very -- or $8.7 billion in unfunded for this quarter, a very small amount of it really is in sort of that money motion. A very small amount of the fixed income. So fixed income is probably 2/3 of that $8.7 billion, and of that, a very modest amount, really less than 10% of it is from money in motion. I think this is a long-term story. I think it will kind of ebb and flow. It will go in waves. That's been what our managers expect. I don't think we've seen the most of it, I think it has the potential to be substantial. And don't forget that it's not just about takeover wins, but it's about new cash wins. And I think as it relates to that, for those that maybe are on the fence or not sure if they're going to switch mandates, they are certainly in our view. We think it's a very high probability that they would diversify so that we'll have greater opportunity with new cash flows, but also the opportunity for takeover wins continues. But again that's going to take some time.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And just making sure, expectation setting, if 2/3 was the money in motion, we should be looking for that kind of thing in each and every quarter, obviously? Your performance is great, your global distribution's leveraging it, but 10 [ph] in a qua
componenttext: Got you. And just making sure, expectation setting, if 2/3 was the money in motion, we should be looking for that kind of thing in each and every quarter, obviously? Your performance is great, your global distribution's leveraging it, but 10 [ph] in a quarter seems to be a really good quarter.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it was a really good quarter. I think you're right. We'd love to see it. We're not going to project really anything because we can't. We do have a strong RFI and RFP pipeline. What that equates to, we're not going to get into it exactly, but I thi
componenttext: I think it was a really good quarter. I think you're right. We'd love to see it. We're not going to project really anything because we can't. We do have a strong RFI and RFP pipeline. What that equates to, we're not going to get into it exactly, but I think the opportunity remains significant. But it's going to take some time. 1 year, 2 years, and it's going to be kind of lumpy along the way.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question is from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our final question is from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, just curious to get your take on trends you may be seeing across the institutional landscape in terms of investors potentially derisking or shifting into more passive mandates. Just from an asset allocation standpoint, either as you look across you
componenttext: First, just curious to get your take on trends you may be seeing across the institutional landscape in terms of investors potentially derisking or shifting into more passive mandates. Just from an asset allocation standpoint, either as you look across your clients here in the U.S. or overseas.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you've -- the derisking trend remains intact. We expect to continue to see clients look to kind of to derisk their portfolios and locl in their games, lock in their liabilities. But again, that will be a long-term type of thing. And frankly, the v
componenttext: I think you've -- the derisking trend remains intact. We expect to continue to see clients look to kind of to derisk their portfolios and locl in their games, lock in their liabilities. But again, that will be a long-term type of thing. And frankly, the volatility in the equity markets slows that down a little bit, right? So we do see that happening and that we are experience some of that, but we think that that's a longer-term trend as well. As it relates to sort of the past, even in that whole question, whether it be retail or institutional. And I said this in my prepared remarks, we feel just very strongly that there is a role for both, right? We do believe that there is a role for both. But particularly right now in fixed income, it feels like about the worst time to be passive in your investing because it doesn't allow for you to try to negate or hedge in some way or otherwise object to the requirements and the lack of flexibility that you have when you're benchmark investing. So quite frankly, I think increasingly, with rates where they are, and where the -- there is a general consensus. Rates are going to move higher at some point, whether it's shorter term, longer term, they're going to move higher. There's obviously a lot of currency impact in the markets, there's a lot of credit, both corporate credit and sovereign risk issues out there. And just simply passively investing exposes you in a way and exposes clients in a way that we think is a mistake, and increasingly, our clients are listening to that and hearing that. So we think the opportunity for active management broadly speaking is important. We have to demonstrate it and prove it, nowhere more so than in fixed income right now.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe just 1 follow-up for Pete. Just given kind of the ongoing volatility in the FX markets. And I know you disclosed the FX impact AUM every month, but any color on potentially framing the EPS risk just assuming the dollar continues to stren
componenttext: Got it. And maybe just 1 follow-up for Pete. Just given kind of the ongoing volatility in the FX markets. And I know you disclosed the FX impact AUM every month, but any color on potentially framing the EPS risk just assuming the dollar continues to strengthen? I know you mentioned being somewhat naturally hedged, but just curious to get a sense of how material that might be.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So we talk about oil as well and energy because it was a question that didn't come up but I'm sure is on people's minds. But the FX impact for us is almost de minimus. We've been watching the dollar strengthened against the yen, the euro, the.
componenttext: Yes, sure. So we talk about oil as well and energy because it was a question that didn't come up but I'm sure is on people's minds. But the FX impact for us is almost de minimus. We've been watching the dollar strengthened against the yen, the euro, the. pound, pretty much the w hole year. And the total impact for us is probably about a penny or a bit more than that in terms of earnings per share. So pretty much naturally hedged to our expense pool and P&L overseas. And part of that is we get a lot more dollar investment from overseas, but they come in, in U.S. dollar in many cases. The other thing I would add is on oil because we've got several exposures there, both on the equity and fixed income side. And equity we're about 6% across all of our portfolios. That compares to broad market indices, which we'd say, energy would be an 8% weighting. So overall, we're under market exposed to start with, but about half of our exposure is Clearbridge and their MLP vehicles, mostly are focused on midstream, so transportation pipelines in particular. They tend not to move directly. Their earnings still move with the price of oil, and they will benefit from longer term. If oil stays down for longer, there will be more demand for transportation. So we're not too worried about the MLPs. When you take those out, we're less than 4% exposed on the equity side. So half of market exposure in energy. And pretty much a similar story in fixed income. Less than 3% of our fixed income portfolio's exposed to energy. There isn't really a broad market index where we can look at a number of different ones. We look at all of them total we see the market in fixed income be ming like 5% to 6%. So again, we're less than half in both of the spaces. Is that helpful?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. And thanks to all of you listening for your time this morning and for your interest in Legg Mason. As I said during my opening remarks, I am quite pleased with our continued progress and prospects for Legg Mason. We are truly building mom
componenttext: Thank you, John. And thanks to all of you listening for your time this morning and for your interest in Legg Mason. As I said during my opening remarks, I am quite pleased with our continued progress and prospects for Legg Mason. We are truly building momentum. and the 5 key takeaways that I put forth are key to that progress and momentum. Investment performance for our clients remain strong. We have expanded and enhanced our product lineup in a meaningful way. We have returned to growth with positive net flows for 3 straight quarters. Our balance sheet strong, and our cash generation robust. And our commitment to invest in our business while returning capital to shareholders remains. The opportunities before us are substantial, and I look forward to updating you on our progress again next quarter. And with that, I wish you a good day.
