componenttext: Thank you. This concludes today's teleconference. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect at this time.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Legg Mason First Fiscal Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is John, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this teleconference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your hos
componenttext:
Welcome to the Legg Mason First Fiscal Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is John, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this teleconference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Alan Magleby, Head of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Thank you. Mr. Magleby, you may begin.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2016 first quarter ended June 30, 2015.This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the
componenttext:
Thank you. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2016 first quarter ended June 30, 2015.
This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not statements of facts or guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed in the statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see risk factors and management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, and in the company's subsequent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
During the call today, we may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the non-GAAP financial measures to the comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the press release that we issued this morning, which is available in the Investor Relations section of our website. The company undertakes no obligation to update the information contained in this presentation to reflect subsequently occurring events or circumstances.
This morning's call will include remarks from Mr. Joe Sullivan, Legg Mason's Chairman and CEO; and Mr. Pete Nachtwey, Legg Mason's CFO, who will discuss our financial results. In addition, following the review of the company's quarter, we will then open the call to Q&A, for which we will include Tom Hoops, Legg Mason's Head of Business Development. 
Now, I would like to turn this call over to Mr. Joe O'Sullivan. Joe?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan. And as always, we appreciate your interest in Legg Mason. I am pleased to report that Legg Mason delivered solid financial performance for the quarter and continued to make strategic progress against our longer-term goals. We recorded o
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan. And as always, we appreciate your interest in Legg Mason. 
I am pleased to report that Legg Mason delivered solid financial performance for the quarter and continued to make strategic progress against our longer-term goals. We recorded our fifth straight quarter of net long-term inflows driven by Western Asset, Brandywine Global, QS investors and Martin Currie. Revenues grew modestly and our bottom line included the effect of seasonal deferred compensation expense, which Pete will walk you through in more detail. 
Our unfunded wins totaling $12 billion at quarter's end, some of which has funded in July, were also strong underscoring the diversification of our business mix across asset class, client type and geography. 
As you all know, this has been a challenging time for the markets for our investors and by extension, our industry.  Investors are inundated with headlines and financial programs that highlight a multitude of issues that they're dealing with today including high equity valuations globally, the implications of rising rates as well as broad geopolitical uncertainty.
On a daily basis, they are trying to navigate such complex issues as a potential Greece default, China slowdown, and market volatility as well as terrorism, none of which inspire confidence, particularly for retail investors. Such consternation has caused investors to pause, which is evidenced by quarterly industry flow data, most notably the $49 billion in outflows in active U.S. equity funds and $6 billion in active U.S. bond fund outflows during the quarter. 
I am pleased to report, however, $1.3 billion in net inflows for the quarter, driven by fixed income. This is especially gratifying given the market and industry headwinds that I just described.
We continue to be very pleased with the success we are experiencing with QS Investors. We're encouraged by the early traction at Martin Currie, particularly in Australia, and we are quite excited by the recent announcement of our acquisition of RARE Infrastructure, which will expand our capabilities in liquid alternatives, specifically listed infrastructure, which we project to be long-term high-growth investment space. Again, all in all a solid quarter against a backdrop of a challenging environment. 
Now, let me walk you through some of the details.
Slide 2 highlights our financial results. We generated net income of $94.5 million or $0.84 per diluted share. And ended the quarter with assets under management of just under $700 billion and as I mentioned, with long-term net inflows of $1.3 billion.
Global Distribution recorded gross and net sales of $19 billion and $1.1 billion, respectively, and we retired 1.7 million shares during the quarter.
Slide 3 shows our assets under management by affiliate. I'll go into more detail on the next slide. However, I continue to be very pleased with the diversification across our affiliate portfolio and in particular, how our affiliates are differentiated distribution channels and varied geographic mix can balance each other across market cycles. And now, with the announced acquisition of RARE Infrastructure, combined with continued product development across new and legacy affiliates, we will be even more diversified as we grow the business.
Slide 4 shows fund flows and unfunded wins at quarter end by affiliates. Again, it is here where you can see the impact of our business diversity. Let's start with fixed income flows. 
We continue to believe that Legg Mason is well positioned even as interest rates rise, and in fact, as I've said too many of you, we firmly believe that higher normalized rates will ultimately be good for our fixed income business. If you recall in previous rising rate cycles, corporate credit and strategic income strategies, both strengths of our fixed income affiliates, actually saw meaningful inflows. We also see institutional investors rebalancing and increasing their allocations to fixed income broadly and to LDI strategies in particular in a higher rate environment.
Western Asset achieved $1 billion in net long-term inflows during the quarter with 8 of the largest 10 new counts driven by specialized mandates. Western's quarter end 1 but not yet funded pipeline stood at $2.3 billion. While retail fixed income flows have slowed a bit nearly 90% of Webster's AUM is institutional, which tends to be longer term in nature. Western is delivering strong performance broadly across assets and consistent experience momentum with consultants, both of which bode well for the growth of their institutional business. 
Fixed income inflows at Brandywine Global were $1.7 billion reflecting strong flows in both separate accounts and cross-border funds. $2 billion of Brandywine's 1 but not yet funded pipeline is in fixed income with just over $1 billion having funded this month. Finally, Brandywine's institutional sales pipeline continues to look very robust.
Now on to equities.
Inflows at QS Investors, Brandywine and Martin Currie were offset by outflows at Royce and ClearBridge as weakness in the U.S. equity markets accelerated retail outflows. After 9 consecutive quarters of inflows, ClearBridge had net outflows of $800 million driven primarily by a slowing of retail sales and reallocation sub-advisory accounts, which are often seasonal in nature.
Royce experienced outflows again in the quarter and as we've said for a while now, returning to sustained net inflows will take some time.
Now I've spent a good amount of time with Royce and can say with conviction name that we continue to believe in their long-term investment process and are very supportive of the steps that they've taken to strengthen their investment platform in the meantime.
QS Investors recorded $1.7 billion in net inflows and $3.4 billion in unfunded wins at quarter end driven by the sub-advisory takeover wins that we've discussed on previous calls. Approximately $3 billion of those wins have funded in July. QS is a significant component of our new product development with 9 additional products expected to be launched this year. We are very energized by the strong partnership between QS, our product teams and Global Distribution and we continue to see grade long-term potential for continued growth.
Brandywine had net inflows of $400 million in equities and $3 billion of their total unfunded wins are across a number of their equity products. With strong investment performance, these products are seeing robust institutional interest.
Martin Currie had $100 million of inflows and ended the quarter with $500 million in unfunded wins. Martin Currie has enjoyed early momentum with real asset strategies managed by their Australian team, while we continue to integrate their products at and commercialize their strategies across our global distribution platform.
And finally, alternatives. Permal's flows were negative for the quarter so that doesn't really tell the entire story. Our reported AUM number for Permal does not include strong inflows into an Assets Under Advisement product in China, which was nearly $800 million for the quarter. While classified as Assets Under Advisement, this product has attractive fee characteristics, which while lower than Permal's typical retail or institutional fees, are still quite compelling. China continues to be a significant strategic opportunity and we're very encouraged by Permal's progress there.
As a reminder, nearly 70% of Permal's AUM is institutional currently as they continue to transition their business away from the European high network market. Broader, U.S. retail for Permal continues to slowly build momentum with products any more shelf space and intermediaries and we are just now launching a cross-border version of Permal's liquid alternative strategies that we believe will attract strong interest.
We announced earlier this week our agreement to acquire RARE Infrastructure, a firm with very attractive products and performance in global listed infrastructure, which is consistent with our strategy of acquiring you a differentiated investment capability that can be leveraged through our global distribution platform. So this is actually good segue to spend a minute on this acquisition.
Let's start on Slide 5 with why this transaction is so compelling. Infrastructure, as an asset class, is very applicable to many investor objectives, specifically growth, income and capital preservation. These are global investment themes that we are addressing through ongoing product development in outcome oriented products and through M&A, such as this transaction. The listed infrastructure space is growing quickly and yet, the opportunity is still developing, which gives us the opportunity to be a market leader in a rapidly growing area.
We believe base supply of listed infrastructure investment opportunities should continue to expand as governments modernize and upgrade infrastructure. At the same time, fiscal constraints will compel governments across the globe to increasingly access the private sector to finance these projects. 
RARE is a market leader in listed infrastructure funds, particularly in Australia and Canada markets that have been early adopters of this asset class. Their investment team has an excellent long-term track record with performance that consistently beats of their stated return objectives.
RARE offers a broad suite of products in both developing and emerging markets and has seen assets double the past 3 years, which highlights the potential of this business as we leverage it with our global retail distribution platform and introduce and market their products in the U.S., Europe and Asia.
Obviously, we have developed a high degree of confidence in the RARE team. These are infrastructure professionals who now manage funds, not fund managers who have decided to create infrastructure products. Further, the founders have done a great job building a strong bench of investment talent and leadership under them.
As is always critical, we have come to appreciate RARE's culture and how well it will fit within Legg Mason, smart people, talented people, good people.
Finally, this is Legg Mason's first transaction where we are leaving founder equity within the affiliate by purchasing less than 100% of the company. As we've discussed on previous earnings call, we believe management equity is essential to optimizing long-term alignment. 
Slide 6 shows the performance of Legg Mason's global distribution platform for the quarter, which I would once again, characterize as solid.
Gross sales of $19 billion, while down from last quarter, were up 17% from the same quarter last year. The drop in gross sales, when combined with some of the sub-advisory reallocations in the quarter, contributed to a drop in net sales although distribution was still net positive inflows overall. Additionally, our investment in distribution is starting to bear fruit with a 65% increase in gross sales from certain previously undercovered advisers in the U.S.
And finally, we continue to work closely with the SEC to obtain all the necessary approvals to offer strategies in an ETF wrapper and we look forward to be able to provide more color with respect to our ETF plans in the near future.
Slide 7 shows our performance in the critical 3- and 5-year window across our strategy AUM and our long-term U.S. fund average.
Performance at a few of our affiliates dipped a bit in this quarter largely impacted by energy prices and emerging markets weakness. 
And with that, let me turn the call over to Pete. Pete?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. I'll pick up on Slide 8. Despite the industry headwinds Joe mentioned earlier, we are pleased to report continued long-term inflows along with earnings of $95 million or $0.84 per share for the quarter. At a high level, our revenues increas
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. I'll pick up on Slide 8. Despite the industry headwinds Joe mentioned earlier, we are pleased to report continued long-term inflows along with earnings of $95 million or $0.84 per share for the quarter. 
At a high level, our revenues increased primarily due to an additional day in the quarter and a 1% increase in average long-term AUM, which more than offset lower performance fees. At the same time, our earnings benefited from some one-time tax items mainly related to New York City tax code changes, which collectively contributed approximately $18 million or $0.16 per share to our quarterly results.
On the expense side, as we indicated on our last call, the increase from the prior quarter was a result of higher seasonal compensation expenses. This increase was somewhat elevated from the prior year seasonal impacts due to accounting charges related to a slightly higher number of retirement eligible employees receiving annual deferred compensation awards. 
Additionally, this quarter was impacted by severance packages for several highly compensated employees. 
Adjusted income was $129 million for the quarter or $1.14 per share. This quarter's performance fees of $19 million came from Permal, Brandywine and Western. These were at the higher end of our expectations as a result of strong performance particularly at Permal and Brandywine. While impossible to predict with precision, we estimate that next quarter's performance fees could be in the range of $10 million to $20 million. 
In terms of capital deployment this quarter, we again retired $90 million in shares. In addition, 1 million shares of stock were granted as part of our annual incentive compensation, so our weighted average shares were reduced by approximately 400,000.
Moving on to Slide 9, the only additional item to highlight here is our GAAP effective tax rate of 21%. This quarter's rate is lower than normal resulting largely from the New York City tax changes that I mentioned earlier. The tax outlook for next quarter is a return to a GAAP effective rate of approximately 36%.
And as we've consistently highlighted, our actual cash tax rate continues to run at a substantially lower level than our GAAP cap rate. Specifically, for this quarter we were at 6% and for the full fiscal year, we expect a cash tax rate of 5%, as you can see on page 20 in the appendix. This lower cash rate is anticipated to last at least through the end of this decade based on our current estimates.
Turning to Slide 10, our Assets Under Management were down 1% compared to the prior quarter driven by market depreciation of $7 billion. This more than offset positive net long-term and liquidity flows.
On slide 11, you can see the long-term inflows were $1.3 billion and represented our fifth straight quarter of positive long-term inflows. Fixed income inflows of $2.6 billion reflected our strong performance in areas of market demand across a variety of strategies and products. Equity flows were negative though small cap being a primary driver. 
Looking ahead, our July flows will be positive based on what we know at the moment driven by equity wins including a large custom asset allocation mandate and a variety of institutional fixed income wins, although we anticipate these will be partially offset by the ongoing redemptions at Royce.
You will see on slide 12, that we're disclosing our total operating revenue yield ex performance fees. We feel this view is a more helpful depiction of our revenue yield trends and will help you more accurately model our revenues going forward. This quarter's higher rate was primarily due to the growth in average long-term AUM along with a decline in average lower fee liquidity AUM.
Operating expenses on Slide 13 increased by $11 million or 2% to $584 million. I will discuss comp and benefits on the next slide, but looking at the other line items, DNS expense increased reflecting 1 additional day in the quarter along with cost related emerging certain fund raises in Europe. Also I want to highlight for this quarter, we expect DNS expense to remain at the 22% level we saw in the June quarter. 
Other expenses decreased $5 million as the prior quarter's expenses included higher advertising and consulting spend. 
Turning to Slide 14, compensation and benefits increased by $12 million, while benefits and payroll taxes were up $17 million largely due to the increase in seasonal cost. $7 million of that increase was affiliate related and thus, offset and salary and incentives. Additionally, the seasonal cost included $9 million of incremental accounting charges related to annual deferred compensation awards to retirement eligible employees. The compensation and benefits ratio came in at 56%, higher than our full year expected range due to these seasonal factors. We do expect this ratio to drop back down to the 53% to 54% range for the remainder of fiscal 2016.
Slide 15 highlights the operating margin as adjusted, which decreased from last quarter's 23.8%. The incremental impact of the retirement eligible accounting charges on the current quarter's operating margin was 1.7%, so we expect our margin to improve next quarter as these costs abate.
Slide 16 is a roll forward from fiscal Q4's GAAP earnings per share of $0.73 to this quarter's $0.84 per share. Fiscal Q4 was a pretty clean quarter only impacted by a lower tax rate, which increased last quarter's earnings per share by $0.03.
This quarter, higher revenues were offset by the seasonally higher benefit cost, which combined to reduce earnings per share by a penny. The change in mark-to-market on our seed investments decreased earnings per share also by a penny. And finally, for fiscal Q1, as I previously noted, that's changes increased earnings per share by $0.16.
I'll wrap up on Slide 17, which highlights our quarterly cash position as well as our consistent and balanced approach to capital deployment. In the upper left, you can see that we have steadily reduced our share count by 53 million shares or 32% since March 2010. While in the upper right, we have highlighted the change in our quarterly dividend over the same timeframe. We now have 6 straight years of increased annual dividends and we're particularly proud of that magnitude of those increases since 2010, which is approaching 600%.
And as you can see, in total, we returned a very robust $2.4 billion in capital to our shareholders over the last 5 years, a rate of return that is industry-leading.
On the bottom left, you can see our cash position, which has been relatively consistent over the past year. As expected, our cash balance is at its typical seasonal low point for the year due to cash bonuses paid in mid-May.
Finally on the bottom right, we highlight our current seed investments of $328 million across a diversified portfolio by asset class. This is a $63 million decrease from fiscal Q4 as we were able to redeem some of our seed investments from products that no longer required capital support. 
So thank you for your time and for your interest in Legg Mason. Now, I'll turn it back over to Joe.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pete. Legg Mason has a truly global perspective, capability set and footprint, which guides us in delivering products that address and solve the increasingly complex needs of investors. I want to emphasize once again that we are well positioned
componenttext:
Thanks, Pete. Legg Mason has a truly global perspective, capability set and footprint, which guides us in delivering products that address and solve the increasingly complex needs of investors. 
I want to emphasize once again that we are well positioned in fixed income even with a potential U.S. interest rate hike on the horizon. With nearly 90% of our fixed income business institutional in nature, we believe that demand from investors will remain strong particularly for the credit, absolute return, global and unconstrained products in which Brandywine and Western Asset have long track records and excellent performance.
We continue to believe strongly in active management in fixed income and the data clearly shows that core, active fixed income managers have consistently and meaningfully beaten their benchmarks over time. This fact reflects the flawed construction of fixed income indices and the diversity of investment opportunity to active managers. And we believe our active fixed income managers have demonstrated, time and again, that they are among the best in the business.
Obviously, a rising rate environment will also make our money market offerings more attractive and we believe that Western is well positioned after evolving their product set to capture opportunities as regulatory reform is implemented.
We don't often talk about this, but rising interest rates and the more normalized economic and market environment that they represent should also provide opportunity for our active equity managers, particularly Permal and Royce, whose investments styles have been out of favor in this persistently and abnormally low rate environment. 
We continue to fill product gaps and strengthen and diversify our affiliate portfolio. We are very pleased with the initial work to commercialize the investment capabilities that QS Investors and Martin Currie have brought to us. The momentum that QS Investors is showing particularly in the insurance sub-advisory space is very encouraging.
The progress that our ETF team has made in building an infrastructure to offer strategies in an ETF wrapper is also very exciting. As I mentioned, we are working diligently with the SEC and look forward to providing an update after necessary approvals are obtained.
The pending acquisition of RARE Infrastructure will bring a highly regarded, deeply experienced team with a focus on d liquid alternative asset class that has significant opportunity to grow. 
And finally, Legg Mason continues to deliver organic growth and we believe our pipeline represents significant opportunity to capture assets across an increasingly diversified affiliate portfolio. Our unfunded wins and pipeline are diverse highlighting the strong performance of client-relevant products across our affiliates. As we continue to bring these products to market and engage the advisers who partner with us, we expect to continue to further capture market share globally. 
And finally, as we execute against our strategic business plans, we intend to optimize shareholder returns through buybacks and growing our dividend over time. 
And now, we look forward to taking your questions.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, good morning, Bill. I'll turn it over to Tom Hoops to give a little bit of detail, but when you think about this transaction, it ticks all the boxes for us. It's a classic Legg Mason transaction. It's both strategically and financially accretive. Th
componenttext: Sure, good morning, Bill. I'll turn it over to Tom Hoops to give a little bit of detail, but when you think about this transaction, it ticks all the boxes for us. It's a classic Legg Mason transaction. It's both strategically and financially accretive. The way we think about it, it brings incremental investment capabilities. That's what we have said be a wanted to do. It got great products and terrific investment performance. Those products secondly certainly are in the next generation product, specifically liquid alts. And then we do view U.S. as being sort of an early mover in what is a burgeoning asset class, so we're excited about that. And then thirdly, it has the potential to significantly leverage LMGD and I think that was last part of your question. I'll let Tom pickup sort of the strategic and a little bit more.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Bill. So you're right, in the early aftermarkets of Australia and Canada, RARE has captured significant share. In a matter of fact, they are the largest they are in the listed mutual funds space. If you look data in Australia, their value in
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Bill. So you're right, in the early aftermarkets of Australia and Canada, RARE has captured significant share. In a matter of fact, they are the largest they are in the listed mutual funds space. If you look data in Australia, their value in their EM funds comprise about 39% of that market and in Canada, the sub-advised fund, which is basically a clone of fund, has about 45% market share. And so, from me that's kind of 2 main things that come out of that. First, I think it's a testament to the quality of the franchise and the credibility of the team and certainly the performance of the products. But secondly, it really points to the LMGD opportunity that we have in partnering with RARE. They have spent very little time and energy and effort looking to grow their business in the U.S. and in Europe and in Asia and certainly if you know on our LMGD platform, that's where we're very well positioned. So we will look to continue to leverage some of their existing UCITS programs into the cross-border space. We'll probably be increased the registrations there. The uss will create on new vehicles but we think in the near term, we can't access the insurance sub-advisory space and our multi-asset class solutions.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: Yes, and that's, to Tom's point, Bill, that to bed done successfully with QS right, so it's taken time to get QS  on platforms and there were sending to get close with U.S. of those platforms, but in the meantime, our insurance sub-advisory team has achieved significant takeover wins and we would expect to kind of take that same model with RARE.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, we do believe that, and as we've said in addition to all the other vehicles in which we offer investment strategies globally, we need to be prepared to make certain of our strategies available in ETF form. This is the belief that drove our rec
componenttext: Sure. Look, we do believe that, and as we've said in addition to all the other vehicles in which we offer investment strategies globally, we need to be prepared to make certain of our strategies available in ETF form. This is the belief that drove our recent hires to build out an ETF capability for Legg Mason. We do believe that at least some of our active strategies can be delivered in a fully transparent form. We've talked about that. But if and as we see the need for nontransparent ETF activities, we'll continue to consider what available vehicles are ultimately best for our clients. As a reminder, we are one of the largest providers of retail SMAs in the business so we've long been accustomed to a greater degree of transparency. One of the great opportunities we do see, however, is the evolution of what many call, smart beta, and we see that as an opportunity to evolve the passive market beyond kind of the traditional market cap weighted strategies by using different factor based strategies that really better reflect client objectives. These types of products, these smart beta types of products maybe best offered in an ETF vehicle so we want to be prepared to be able to do that. As for our recent SEC filings, at this point, it's really not appropriate for us to comment why they're still in the process.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: As for QS, what we're seeing is kind of threefold with them. They're continuing to build and grow their direct consultant driven institutional business, the business that they had prior to our acquisition. We're also -- we've also been working with them s
componenttext: As for QS, what we're seeing is kind of threefold with them. They're continuing to build and grow their direct consultant driven institutional business, the business that they had prior to our acquisition. We're also -- we've also been working with them sort of on a number of retail fronts as we've talked about to get them on platforms and to be able to begin to accrue ongoing kind of consistent flows. We're seeing that happen. That's slow. Those are not takeover wins. Those are just position is that allow for you to get flows over time. And then through the insurance sub-advised space, that's really where we've had pretty quick success with them in terms of, in some cases, topping up existing strategies frankly that came from our Batterymarch platform but the larger takeover wins really are more aligned with multi-asset class type allocation strategies. And we just see continued demand for that. Their pipeline of interest and activity is very, very strong. We are, as I think I mentioned on -- in my remarks, we've also got a significant pipeline of product development. They've got 9 different products right now in the pipeline looking to come forward, so that's really an reflection of the highly customize multi-asset class, multiple allocation strategies that they do. As for Brandywine, it's just -- it's a breadth of very high-quality traditional products. They've got some good large-cap products as well as some good more -- what am I trying to say? Next-generation products and things like that. It's just that -- it's nothing particularly unique. It's just good quality kind of traditional products, frankly more classic generation or classic strategy products that are performing very well.

componenttext: Yes, good morning, Michael. Thanks for your question. Our typical run rate and other expenses I think most of you know are more in the $50 million range. It was just a lot of different things in the mix that favorably impacted this quarter, but we expect next quarter to bounce back up to that $50 million range. We're going to have a couple of things in the quarter, both our annual director compensation that gets awarded, and we'll have a few cost around the deal that we have got with RARE. We don't have any bank fees, so it's not huge amount to do that they have some lawyers and accountants that we'll need to pay and we're also looking at doing some incremental advertising. But $50 million run rate per quarter's the best way to think about it.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you as a follow-up, Joe, if I think about acquisitions, you and the management space, seems like when you look at QS, you look at Martin Currie, and you look at the base of inflows, or the pipeline already, it just seems like maybe coming i
componenttext: Okay. And then you as a follow-up, Joe, if I think about acquisitions, you and the management space, seems like when you look at QS, you look at Martin Currie, and you look at the base of inflows, or the pipeline already, it just seems like maybe coming in better than expected or faster than expected maybe sometimes you get some dislocation or some outflows. So just wanted to get a sense on when you look at the transactions that you've done, how are they trending relative to expectations? And then, is there something different that you guys are doing before you do these transactions that either you're already anticipating or the clients like the demands there that you know the route of the flows are going to be coming in at a fairly healthy pace? It just seems like it's just been coming in at a pace that you generally you would see some weakness or dislocation as the distribution channels start to ramp up.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, great question, Mike. Well, I think a couple of things. First of all, to be candid, yes, I think we actually outperformed -- when you see a combination much as we did with QS, and acquisition -- any acquisition but then also a combination. If you reca
componenttext: So, great question, Mike. Well, I think a couple of things. First of all, to be candid, yes, I think we actually outperformed -- when you see a combination much as we did with QS, and acquisition -- any acquisition but then also a combination. If you recall, we combined Batterymarch with QS. And whenever you see something like that, you expect that that sort of gives clients an opportunity to rethink and potentially to redeem. We retained much more of the Batterymarch and QS assets through the first year of transition than we expected. So we were pleased with the retention of existing business post acquisition. We've also been and to be perfectly candid with you, surprised at the strength of flows and business with QS. But when you step back and think about it, QS is in the sweet spot right now. We're virtually every type of client that we talked to is interested in talking about and considering customized strategies. And our -- and QS' ability to be able to do that, to be able to understand the needs of the client and then customize a strategy either using ETFs or using some of our managers or some combination of the 2 is really quite compelling. As far as what are we doing differently or better, I just think we're doing a good job of execution. I think, many -- our pipeline, our M&A pipeline is as robust as it's ever been. I think that's a function of the environment. I think it's tougher for smaller managers right now. We know that costs are rising. Fees -- there's pressure on fees, so it's a tough environment for many managers and when they look out there, the ability to joined a firm to retain their investment independence, to retain their operational autonomy, to be able to tap in to this global distribution platform, which I think QS and Martin Currie already, their eyes are wide open with the power and strength of that platform, and then in some cases, some choose to tap into various of our other shared services to realize operational efficiency, that's a pretty good combination. And so, we've just -- I think we're attracting a lot of interest right now and I got to get credit to our distribution teams and our product teams and all of our shared service what we call the value chain of Legg Mason for really executing well and delivering. Now some of those steps just takes time. it takes time, as Tom mentioned and I've talked about before, to get things through the pipe in terms of product creation and the regulatory hurdles and all that kind of stuff. But in the meantime, particularly as it relates to the sub-advisory capability, which is really was Quasi-institutional, we can get moving on that pretty much right away. So I think it's -- we've got an attractive model. We find the right partners. It's got to be the right chemistry and the right culture and then so our business model is drawing them. We have the right culture, we what we believe to be the right culture going in and then I think it's been good execution.

componenttext: So look, I think and I know what Pete kind of time in here, but I think the way we think about it, Dan, is to me, goes back to the tax shield, the fact that we generate a lot of cash and by virtue of that tax shields, we're able to retain a lot of that cash. And so, we are able to do invest in our business as we've done over the last year we've been able to invest in distribution. We are able to continue to maintain a robust seed capital program for affiliates. That's one of the things by the way for smaller managers that are considering joining us. That seed capital program is very attractive. We are able to continue the buyback and we've been increasing our dividend. I don't want to say we can do it all forever, but I'm just saying with our tax shield and the fact we're a big-time cash generator, and importantly, retain that cash, we feel that we're able to kind of navigate through all of this. We've done a number of acquisitions already and then able to kind of maintain a balanced capital deployment approach. Did I miss anything?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I might add a few things, Dan, in terms of what we've done over the last several years really since the crisis and we've done a lot to strengthen the balance sheet, first of all. That's something wanted to make sure we had a fortress balance sheet to
componenttext: No, I might add a few things, Dan, in terms of what we've done over the last several years really since the crisis and we've done a lot to strengthen the balance sheet, first of all. That's something wanted to make sure we had a fortress balance sheet to kind of lean back on. We've also deployed a tremendous amount of cash. So if you look at where our cash was coming out of the crisis, we had a lot of money that was sitting with the balance sheet that wasn't earning much for the shareholder. So we've done some delevering. We've done some smart acquisitions and seed and we've also returned a lot of capital to our shareholders, which we intend to continue to do even with these acquisitions that we've done. So we're continuing at that same pace, the $90 million a quarter that we talked about.

componenttext: Well, thanks, Matt. We're -- specifically, the opportunity I mentioned with respect to China was Permal. That is a strategy that was launched in 2014 with a large Chinese financial institution with whom we enjoy a nice distribution relationship. Importantly, the fund that Permal manages has performed relatively well through all of the turbulence that we've seen in the China markets. And as a result, that strategy we saw -- I think we mentioned about $800 million in flows into the strategy just in the last quarter. The strategy now has a total of about $1.5 billion. I would say that as it relates to sort of the attractiveness of that business, it's a lower fee rate than what their traditional institutional or retail fees would be, but they have opportunities. It's still an attractive management fee and they do have opportunities for incentive fees associated with it. As part is how it extends beyond just Permal I mean I can't give you of what the growth rate could be, it could be significant, a good -- those flows can be a bit volatile, to be candid with you. We're about it. It bodes well for Permal. But those can be volatile so we can't really predict what they will be. But what I'll tell you is that all of our affiliates really are in dialogue with Legg Mason, with our Global Distribution platform in terms of how can we extend the success at Permal and with this distributor into other products and then to other channels in China. That's fast it's a market. It's a difficult market to penetrate. We do cover it currently. We do not have a retail distribution office in China. We cover that or have our Hong Kong office responsible for that. But there's a lot of dialogue around how do we kind of if you will do success that we're seeing with this distribution partner and with potential other distribution partners in China for other affiliates. We do see opportunity there and we're excited about it.

componenttext: Sure. There was. I appreciate the question. So recall, we always highlight an uptick in compensation in the first 2 calendar quarters every year. But as you're talking about specifics, I can walk through that. In the March quarter, that's only social factors kind of resetting as well as 401k matches and profit-sharing. Then in the June quarter, all those factors continue up until the point we pay bonuses and at that stage, high earners all kind of get above the limits for those programs. But the other thing we had going on in the June quarter is that's also when we make our annual equity and deferred compensation awards. And as I mentioned on the call, there's retirement people get within 4 years of our normal retirement age, which is the to, GAAP accounting requires you to kind of short even though the lesson. So 4 years and people can vest after they've hypothetically reword so we have good levers to complete, don't solicit. But the accounting rules changed a number of years ago on that. If you're say 59, you now get a 3-year service period even though legally vaguely, it's a four-year period. So that had any impact in the quarter of about $0.05. This year, it about a $0.02 impact after, so we have it every year. It was just a little bit elevated this year. We had a few high earners that hit it. But is basically just accounting noise. It's accelerating the expense be taken away. And it's basically no impact in terms of cash from or no impact to our cash bottom line earnings. And as I think from the most what is being for everyone on the call is we expect next quarter to drop back to the 53%, 54% that we've been guiding to and blended average by the time we get to the end of the year will be by the end of 53%, 54% visit our current projections. Is that when it's a big Saudi does that help?

componenttext: No, it definitely does help. One more for Joe, I was intrigued by your comment about some fundamentals to the drawbacks to fixed income indexes. And I just want to sort sharpening understanding of that. Could you start of build on your comments. What is -- what is it about fixed income indexes that somehow that doesn't capture your strength or make some decisions?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, first of all, they capture probably -- their market waited -- first of all, they're market-weighted much like the equity indexes. So the biggest issuers and to be -- have the highest percentage capture in the index itself. In the broader kind
componenttext: Well, look, first of all, they capture probably -- their market waited -- first of all, they're market-weighted much like the equity indexes. So the biggest issuers and to be -- have the highest percentage capture in the index itself. In the broader kind of the Barclays AG, which everybody uses and is kind of the main benchmark in the index, I think it's only 35% -- of the eligible securities in fixed income, only 35% are captured within that index. So that tells you that there's a whole world out there, 2/3, 2 times as many securities and asset classes within fixed income that can be used and in fact, active managers do use to kind of position their portfolio for different types of market environments. As you can imagine, given what's happened with the U.S. government over the last really since the crises, the massive increase that we've seen a government issuance, treasuries are included in that index. So consequently, given that it's a market cap weighted index, the U.S. Treasury component of it has been significantly -- has significantly increased. So that really allows for active managers who have the flexibility to go beyond that 35% of available products and strategies in fixed income to outperform governments and spread products, and credit products, and unconstrained types of securities have the potential to significantly outperform treasuries. So the index itself is no much more treasury our government -- U.S. government security related than it was even before the crisis because of the massive issuance of the government. The fact that -- look, it's different certainly, in equities, but on the fixed income side, roughly 70% of all active income managers beat the benchmark. Some of them like us like Brandywine and Western, beat it big time. But even the kind of average median fixed income manager can be, it's just not that hard. So for people that are going to the index, we think they're making a choice to underperform over time, at least underperform their opportunity, for sure.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As I've done on the last few calls, I just like to share what I believe to be are the 5 key takeaways for this past quarter. First of all another quarter of organic growth, our fifth straight quarter of positive net flows again, against a fai
componenttext:
Thank you. As I've done on the last few calls, I just like to share what I believe to be are the 5 key takeaways for this past quarter. 
First of all another quarter of organic growth, our fifth straight quarter of positive net flows again, against a fairly challenging market backdrop. Secondly, opportunities for continued growth remain with our unfunded pipeline when, strong across affiliates and progress within our global distribution platform continuing. Thirdly, we are well positioned to capture in a rising rate environment and we welcome a return to rate normalization. Fourth, we continue to diversify our lineup of client offerings through a robust product development pipeline, a robust M&A pipeline and now, the acquisition of RARE Infrastructure.
And lastly, our focus on prudent strategic business investment relatively returning capital to shareholders via share repurchases and dividends will continue.
These 5 key takeaways speak to executing on a plan that we've shared with you for some time now. We intend to continue to deliver on that plan. 
So I'd like to thank you for your continued interest in and confidence in Legg Mason, and I look forward to updating you on our continued progress next quarter. Thank you.
