headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2016 first quarter ended June 30, 2015.This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the
componenttext:
Thank you. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2016 first quarter ended June 30, 2015.
This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not statements of facts or guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed in the statements. For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see risk factors and management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015, and in the company's subsequent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
During the call today, we may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the non-GAAP financial measures to the comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the press release that we issued this morning, which is available in the Investor Relations section of our website. The company undertakes no obligation to update the information contained in this presentation to reflect subsequently occurring events or circumstances.
This morning's call will include remarks from Mr. Joe Sullivan, Legg Mason's Chairman and CEO; and Mr. Pete Nachtwey, Legg Mason's CFO, who will discuss our financial results. In addition, following a review of the company's quarter, we will then open the call to Q&A, for which we will include Tom Hoops, Legg Mason's Head of Business Development, who is available to answer questions about the recently announced RARE transaction.
Now I'd like to turn this call over to Mr. Joe Sullivan. Joe?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan. And as always, we appreciate your interest in Legg Mason. I am pleased to report that Legg Mason delivered solid financial performance for the quarter and continued to make strategic progress against our longer-term goals. We recorded our
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan. And as always, we appreciate your interest in Legg Mason. I am pleased to report that Legg Mason delivered solid financial performance for the quarter and continued to make strategic progress against our longer-term goals. We recorded our fifth straight quarter of net long-term inflows driven by Western Asset, Brandywine Global, QS investors and Martin Currie. Revenues grew modestly, and our bottom line included the effect of seasonal deferred compensation expense, which Pete will walk you through in more detail. Our unfunded wins totaling $12 billion at quarter's end, some of which has funded in July, were also strong, underscoring the diversification of our business mix across asset class, client type and geography. 
As you all know, this has been a challenging time for the markets for our investors and by extension, our industry. Investors are inundated with headlines and financial programs that highlight a multitude of issues that they are dealing with today, including high equity valuations globally, the implications of rising rates, as well as broad geopolitical uncertainty. On a daily basis, they are trying to navigate such complex issues as a potential Greece default, China's slowdown and market volatility, as well as terrorism, none of which inspire confidence, particularly for retail investors. Such consternation has caused investors to pause, which is evidenced by quarterly industry flow data, most notably the $49 billion in outflows in active U.S. equity funds and $6 billion in active U.S. bond fund outflows during the quarter. I am pleased to report, however, $1.3 billion in net inflows for the quarter, driven by fixed income. This is especially gratifying given the market and industry headwinds that I just described. 
We continue to be very pleased with the success we are experiencing with QS Investors. We're encouraged by the early traction at Martin Currie, particularly in Australia, and we are quite excited by the recent announcement of our acquisition of RARE Infrastructure, which will expand our capabilities in liquid alternatives, specifically listed infrastructure, which we project to be a long-term, high-growth investment space. Again all in all, a solid quarter against the backdrop of a challenging environment. 
Now let me walk you through some of the details. Slide 2 highlights our financial results. We generated net income of $94.5 million or $0.84 per diluted share, and ended the quarter with Assets Under Management of just under $700 billion, and as I mentioned, with long-term net inflows of $1.3 billion. Global Distribution recorded gross and net sales of $19 billion and $1.1 billion, respectively, and we retired 1.7 million shares during the quarter.
Slide 3 shows our Assets Under Management by affiliate. I'll go into more detail on the next slide. However, I continue to be very pleased with the diversification across our affiliate portfolio and in particular, how our affiliates, our differentiated distribution channels and varied geographic business mix can balance one another across market cycles. And now with the announced acquisition of RARE Infrastructure, combined with continued product development across new and legacy affiliates, we will be even more diversified as we grow the business.
Slide 4 shows fund flows and unfunded wins at quarter end by affiliate. Again, it is here where you can see the impact of our business diversity. Let's start with fixed income flows. We continue to believe that Legg Mason is well positioned even as interest rates rise, and in fact, as I've said to many of you, we firmly believe that higher normalized rates will ultimately be good for our fixed income business. If you recall, in previous rising rate cycles, corporate credit and strategic income strategies, both strengths of our fixed income affiliates, actually saw meaningful inflows. We also see institutional investors rebalancing and increasing their allocations to fixed income broadly, and to LDI strategies in particular, in a higher rate environment.
Western Asset achieved $1 billion in net long-term inflows during the quarter with 8 of the largest 10 new accounts driven by specialized mandates. Western's quarter-end won but not yet funded pipeline stood at $2.3 billion. While retail fixed income flows have slowed a bit, nearly 90% of Western's AUM is institutional, which tends to be longer term in nature. Western is delivering strong performance broadly across their composites and continues to experience momentum with consultants, both of which bode well for the growth of their institutional business. 
Fixed income inflows at Brandywine Global were $1.7 billion, reflecting strong institutional flows in both separate accounts and cross-border funds. $2 billion of Brandywine's won but not yet funded pipeline is in fixed income, with just over $1 billion having funded this month. Finally, Brandywine's institutional sales pipeline continues to look very robust.
Now on to equities. Inflows at QS Investors, Brandywine and Martin Currie were offset by outflows at Royce and ClearBridge as weakness in the U.S. equity markets accelerated retail outflows. After 9 consecutive quarters of inflows, ClearBridge had net outflows of $800 million, driven primarily by a slowing of retail sales and reallocations in sub-advisory accounts, which are often seasonal in nature.
Royce experienced outflows again in the quarter and, as we've said for a while now, returning to sustained net inflows will take some time. Now I've spent a good amount of time with Royce and can say with conviction that we continue to believe in their long-term investment process and are very supportive of the steps that they've taken to strengthen their investment platform in the meantime.
QS Investors recorded $1.7 billion in net inflows and $3.4 billion in unfunded wins at quarter end, driven by the sub-advisory takeover wins that we've discussed on previous calls. Approximately $3 billion of those wins have funded in July. QS is a significant component of our new product development with 9 additional products expected to be launched this year. We are very energized by the strong partnership between QS, our product teams and Global Distribution, and we continue to see great long-term potential for continued growth.
Brandywine had net inflows of $400 million in equities and $3 billion of their total unfunded wins are across a number of their equity products. With strong investment performance, these products are seeing robust institutional interest. Martin Currie had $100 million of inflows and ended the quarter with $500 million in unfunded wins. Martin Currie has enjoyed early momentum with real asset strategies managed by their Australian team, while we continue to integrate their product set and commercialize their strategies across our Global Distribution platform.
And finally, alternatives. Permal's flows were negative for the quarter, though that doesn't really tell the entire story. Our reported AUM number for Permal does not include strong inflows into an Assets Under Advisement product in China, which was nearly $800 million for the quarter. While classified as Assets Under Advisement, this product has attractive fee characteristics, which, while lower than Permal's typical retail or institutional fees are still quite compelling. China continues to be a significant strategic opportunity, and we're very encouraged by Permal's progress there. As a reminder, nearly 70% of Permal's AUM is institutional currently as they continue to transition their business away from the European high net worth market. Broader U.S. retail for Permal continues to slowly build momentum with products gaining more shelf space at intermediaries, and we are just now launching a cross-border version of Permal's liquid alternative strategies that we believe will attract strong interest.
We announced earlier this week our agreement to acquire RARE Infrastructure, a firm with very attractive products and performance in global listed infrastructure, which is consistent with our strategy of acquiring new and differentiated investment capability that can be leveraged through our Global Distribution platform. So this is actually a good segue to spend a minute on this acquisition.
Let's start on Slide 5 with why this transaction is so compelling. Infrastructure as an asset class is very applicable to many investor objectives, specifically growth, income and capital preservation. These are global investment themes that we are addressing through ongoing product development in outcome-oriented products and through M&A, such as this transaction. The listed infrastructure space is growing quickly, and yet the opportunity is still developing, which gives us the opportunity to be a market leader in a rapidly growing area. We believe the supply of listed infrastructure investment opportunities should continue to expand as governments modernize and upgrade infrastructure. At the same time, fiscal constraints will compel governments across the globe to increasingly access the private sector to finance these projects. 
RARE is a market leader in listed infrastructure funds, particularly in Australia and Canada, markets that have been early adopters of this asset class. Their investment team has an excellent long-term track record with performance that consistently beats their stated return objectives. RARE offers a broad suite of products in both developing and emerging markets and has seen assets double the past 3 years, which highlights the potential of this business as we leverage it with our global retail distribution platform and introduce and market their products in the U.S., Europe and Asia.
Obviously, we have developed a high degree of confidence in the RARE team. These are infrastructure professionals who now manage funds, not fund managers who have decided to create infrastructure products. Further, the founders have done a great job building a strong bench of investment talent and leadership under them. As is always critical, we have come to appreciate RARE's unique culture and how well it will fit within Legg Mason: smart people, talented people, good people. Finally, this is Legg Mason's first transaction, where we are leaving founder equity within the affiliate by purchasing less than 100% of the company. As we've discussed on previous earnings calls, we believe management equity is essential to optimizing long-term alignment. 
Slide 6 shows the performance of Legg Mason's Global Distribution platform for the quarter, which I would once again characterize as solid. Gross sales of $19 billion, while down from last quarter, were up 17% from the same quarter last year. The drop in gross sales, when combined with some of the sub-advisory reallocations in the quarter, contributed to a drop in net sales, although distribution was still net positive in flows overall. Additionally, our investment in distribution is starting to bear fruit, with a 65% increase in gross sales from certain previously undercovered advisers in the U.S. And finally, we continue to work closely with the SEC to obtain all the necessary approvals to offer strategies in an ETF wrapper. And we look forward to be able to provide more color with respect to our ETF plans in the near future.
Slide 7 shows our performance in the critical 3- and 5-year window across our strategy AUM and our long-term U.S. fund average. Performance at a few of our affiliates dipped a bit in this quarter, largely impacted by energy prices and emerging markets weakness. 
And with that, let me turn the call over to Pete. Pete?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. I'll pick up on Slide 8. Despite the industry headwinds Joe mentioned earlier, we are pleased to report continued long-term inflows along with earnings of $95 million or $0.84 per share for the quarter. At a high level, our revenues increased
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. I'll pick up on Slide 8. Despite the industry headwinds Joe mentioned earlier, we are pleased to report continued long-term inflows along with earnings of $95 million or $0.84 per share for the quarter. At a high level, our revenues increased primarily due to an additional day in the quarter and a 1% increase in average long-term AUM, which more than offset lower performance fees. At the same time, our earnings benefited from some onetime tax items, mainly related to New York City tax code changes, which collectively contributed approximately $18 million or $0.16 per share to our quarterly results.
On the expense side, as we indicated on our last call, the increase from the prior quarter was the result of higher seasonal compensation expenses. This increase was somewhat elevated from the prior year's seasonal impacts due to accounting charges related to a slightly higher number of retirement-eligible employees receiving annual deferred compensation awards. Additionally, this quarter was impacted by severance packages for several highly compensated employees. 
Adjusted income was $129 million for the quarter or $1.14 per share. This quarter's performance fees of $19 million came from Permal, Brandywine and Western. These were at the higher end of our expectations as a result of strong performance, particularly at Permal and Brandywine. While impossible to predict with precision, we estimate that next quarter's performance fees could be in the range of $10 million to $20 million. In terms of capital deployment this quarter, we again retired $90 million in shares. In addition, 1 million shares of restricted stock were granted as part of our annual incentive compensation, so our weighted average shares were reduced by approximately 400,000.
Moving on to Slide 9. The only additional item to highlight here is our GAAP effective tax rate of 21%. This quarter's rate is lower than normal, resulting largely from the New York City tax changes that I mentioned earlier. The tax outlook for next quarter is a return to a GAAP effective rate of approximately 36%. And as we have consistently highlighted, our actual cash tax rate continues to run at a substantially lower level than our GAAP rate. Specifically, for this quarter, we were at 6%. And for the full fiscal year, we expect a cash tax rate of 5%, as you can see on Page 20 in the appendix. This lower cash rate is anticipated to last at least through the end of this decade based on our current estimates.
Turning to Slide 10. Our Assets Under Management were down 1% compared to the prior quarter, driven by market depreciation of $7 billion. This more than offset positive net long-term and liquidity flows.
On Slide 11, you can see the long-term inflows were $1.3 billion and represented our fifth straight quarter of positive long-term inflows. Fixed income inflows of $2.6 billion reflected our strong performance in areas of market demand across a variety of strategies and products. Equity flows were negative, with small cap being the primary driver. Looking ahead, our July flows will be positive based on what we know at the moment, driven by equity wins, including a large custom asset allocation mandate and a variety of institutional fixed income wins, although we anticipate these will be partially offset by the ongoing redemptions at Royce.
You will see on Slide 12 that we are disclosing our total operating revenue yield ex performance fees. We feel this view is a more helpful depiction of our revenue yield trends and will help you more accurately model our revenues going forward. This quarter's higher rate was primarily due to the growth in average long-term AUM, along with a decline in average lower fee liquidity AUM.
Operating expenses on Slide 13 increased by $11 million or 2% to $584 million. I will discuss comp and benefits on the next slide. But looking at the other line items, D&S expense increased, reflecting one additional day in the quarter along with costs related to merging certain fund ranges in Europe. Also I wanted to highlight for next quarter, we expect D&S expense to remain at the 22% level we saw in the June quarter. Other expenses decreased $5 million as the prior quarter's expenses included higher advertising and consulting spend. 
Turning to Slide 14. Compensation and benefits increased by $12 million while benefits and payroll taxes were up $17 million, largely due to the increase in seasonal costs. $7 million of that increase was affiliate related, and thus offset in salary and incentives. Additionally, the seasonal costs included $9 million of incremental accounting charges related to annual deferred compensation awards to retirement-eligible employees. The compensation and benefits ratio came in at 56%, higher than our full year expected range due to these seasonal factors. We do expect this ratio to drop back down to the 53% to 54% range for the remainder of fiscal 2016.
Slide 15 highlights the operating margin as adjusted, which decreased from last quarter's 23.8%. The incremental impact of the retirement-eligible accounting charges on the current quarter's operating margin was 1.7%. So we expect our margin to improve next quarter as these costs abate.
Slide 16 is a roll-forward from fiscal Q4's GAAP earnings per share of $0.73 to this quarter's $0.84 per share. Fiscal Q4 was a pretty clean quarter, only impacted by a lower tax rate, which increased last quarter's earnings per share by $0.03. This quarter, higher revenues were offset by the seasonally higher benefit costs, which combined to reduce earnings per share by $0.01. The change in mark-to-market on our seed investments decreased earnings per share also by $0.01. And finally, for fiscal Q1, as I previously noted, tax changes increased earnings per share by $0.16.
I'll wrap up on Slide 17, which highlights our quarterly cash position as well as our consistent and balanced approach to capital deployment. In the upper left, you can see that we have steadily reduced our share count by 53 million shares or 32% since March 2010, while in the upper right, we've highlighted the change in our quarterly dividend over this same time frame. We now have 6 straight years of increased annual dividends, and we are particularly proud of the magnitude of those increases since 2010, which is approaching 600%. And as you can see, in total, we have returned a very robust $2.4 billion in capital to our shareholders over the last 5 years, a rate of return that is industry-leading.
On the bottom left, you can see our cash position, which has been relatively consistent over the past year. As expected, our cash balance is at its typical seasonal low point for the year due to cash bonuses paid in mid-May. Finally on the bottom right, we highlight our current seed investments of $328 million across a diversified portfolio by asset class. This is a $63 million decrease from fiscal Q4, as we were able to redeem some of our seed investments from products that no longer required capital support. 
So thank you for your time and for your interest in Legg Mason. Now I'll turn it back to Joe.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pete. Legg Mason has a truly global perspective, capability set and footprint, which guides us in delivering products that address and solve the increasingly complex needs of investors. I want to emphasize once again that we are well positioned in
componenttext:
Thanks, Pete. Legg Mason has a truly global perspective, capability set and footprint, which guides us in delivering products that address and solve the increasingly complex needs of investors. I want to emphasize once again that we are well positioned in fixed income even with a potential U.S. interest rate hike on the horizon. 
With nearly 90% of our fixed income business institutional in nature, we believe that demand from investors will remain strong, particularly for the credit, absolute return, global and unconstrained products in which Brandywine and Western Asset have long track records and excellent performance. We continue to believe strongly in active management in fixed income and the data clearly shows that core active fixed income managers have consistently and meaningfully beaten their benchmarks over time. This fact reflects the flawed construction of fixed income indices and the diversity of investment opportunity to active managers. And we believe our active fixed income managers have demonstrated time and again that they are among the best in the business. 
Obviously, a rising rate environment will also make our money market offerings more attractive, and we believe that Western is well positioned after evolving their product set to capture opportunities as regulatory reform is implemented. We don't often talk about this, but rising interest rates and the more normalized economic and market environment that they represent should also provide opportunity for our active equity managers, particularly Permal and Royce, whose investment styles have been out of favor in this persistently and abnormally low rate environment. 
We continue to fill product gaps and strengthen and diversify our affiliate portfolio. We are very pleased with the initial work to commercialize the investment capabilities that QS Investors and Martin Currie have brought to us. The momentum that QS Investors is showing, particularly in the insurance sub-advisory space, is very encouraging. The progress that our ETF team has made in building an infrastructure to offer strategies in an ETF wrapper is also very exciting. As I mentioned, we are working diligently with the SEC and look forward to providing an update after necessary approvals are obtained. The pending acquisition of RARE Infrastructure will bring a highly regarded, deeply experienced team with a focus on a liquid alternative asset class that has significant opportunity to grow. 
And finally, Legg Mason continues to deliver organic growth. And we believe our pipeline represents significant opportunity to capture assets across an increasingly diversified affiliate portfolio. Our unfunded wins and pipeline are diverse, highlighting the strong performance of client-relevant products across our affiliates. As we continue to bring these products to market and engage the advisers who partner with us, we expect to continue to further capture market share globally. And finally, as we execute against our strategic business plans, we intend to optimize shareholder returns through buybacks and growing our dividend over time. 
And now we look forward to taking your questions.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Bill Katz from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Bill Katz from Citi.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question maybe just on RARE, so congrats on the deal. Could you talk a little bit about -- Joe, you mentioned that they have been a first mover in Australia and Canada. Could you maybe size how much market penetration they've gotten there? And then
componenttext: First question maybe just on RARE, so congrats on the deal. Could you talk a little bit about -- Joe, you mentioned that they have been a first mover in Australia and Canada. Could you maybe size how much market penetration they've gotten there? And then you mentioned also you think you could leverage this through the Global Distribution and other products. Could you maybe talk a little bit about -- flesh it out a little bit how quickly you think that might come to fruition?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll turn it over to Tom Hoops in a second to get into a little bit of detail. But when you think about this transaction, it kind of ticks all the boxes for us. It's a classic Legg Mason transaction. It's both strategically and financially accretive
componenttext: Sure. I'll turn it over to Tom Hoops in a second to get into a little bit of detail. But when you think about this transaction, it kind of ticks all the boxes for us. It's a classic Legg Mason transaction. It's both strategically and financially accretive. The way we think about it, it brings incremental investment capabilities. That's what we've said we wanted to do. It's got great products and terrific investment performance. Those products, secondly, are in what we've talked about as next-generation products, specifically liquid alts. And then we do view us as being sort of an early mover in what is a burgeoning asset class, so we're excited about that. And then thirdly, it has the potential to significantly leverage LMGD. And I think that was the last part of your question. I'll let Tom pick up sort of on the strategic and a little bit more.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Bill. So you're right. In the early adopter markets of Australia and Canada, RARE has captured significant share. Matter of fact, they are the largest player in the listed mutual fund space there. If you look at Morningstar data, in Australi
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Bill. So you're right. In the early adopter markets of Australia and Canada, RARE has captured significant share. Matter of fact, they are the largest player in the listed mutual fund space there. If you look at Morningstar data, in Australia, their value in their EM funds comprise about 39% of that market. And in Canada, the sub-advised fund, which is basically a clone of their flagship fund, has about 45% market share. And so for me, there's kind of 2 main things that come out of that. First, I think it's a testament to the quality of the franchise and the credibility of the team and then certainly the performance of the products. But secondly, it really points to the LMGD opportunity that we have in partnering with RARE. They have spent very little time and energy and effort looking to grow their business in the U.S. and in Europe and in Asia. And certainly if you know our LMGD platform, that's where we're very well positioned. So we will look to continue to leverage some of their existing UCITS programs into the cross-border space. We'll probably increase the registrations there. The U.S., we'll have to create some new vehicles. But we think in the near term, we can access the insurance sub-advisory space and our multi-asset class solutions.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And that's -- to Tom's point, Bill, that's what we've done successfully with QS, right? So it's taken time to get QS on platforms. And there, we're starting to get flows with QS on those platforms. But in the meantime, our insurance sub-advisory team
componenttext: Yes. And that's -- to Tom's point, Bill, that's what we've done successfully with QS, right? So it's taken time to get QS on platforms. And there, we're starting to get flows with QS on those platforms. But in the meantime, our insurance sub-advisory team has achieved significant takeover wins, and we would expect to kind of take that same model with RARE.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great color. And my follow-up question, and maybe you'll say, "Just wait for it." But just sort of curious, because you teased us a little bit on the ETF side. Could you talk maybe broadly speaking how you're thinking about leveraging ETFs to
componenttext: Okay, that's great color. And my follow-up question, and maybe you'll say, "Just wait for it." But just sort of curious, because you teased us a little bit on the ETF side. Could you talk maybe broadly speaking how you're thinking about leveraging ETFs to take more flow?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, we do believe that, and as we've said, in addition to all the other vehicles in which we offer investment strategies globally, we need to be prepared to make certain of our strategies available in ETF form. This is the belief that drove our re
componenttext: Sure. Look, we do believe that, and as we've said, in addition to all the other vehicles in which we offer investment strategies globally, we need to be prepared to make certain of our strategies available in ETF form. This is the belief that drove our recent hires to build out an ETF capability for Legg Mason. We do believe that at least some of our active strategies can be delivered in a fully transparent form. We've talked about that. But if and as we see the need for nontransparent ETF activities, we'll continue to consider what available vehicles are ultimately best for our clients. As a reminder, we are one of the largest providers of retail SMAs in the business. So we've long been accustomed to a greater degree of transparency. One of the great opportunities we do see, however, is the evolution of what many call smart beta. And we see that as an opportunity to evolve the passive market beyond kind of the traditional market cap weighted strategies by using different factor-based strategies that really better reflect client objectives. These types of products, these smart beta types of products, may be best offered in an ETF vehicle, so we want to be prepared to be able to do that. As for our recent SEC filing, at this point, it's really not appropriate for us to comment while we're still in that process.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So really nice increase in the pipeline, a couple of questions on that. First, as it relates to QS, it's definitely ramped up very quickly. Just wondering how broad-based of a demand you're seeing there for QS among institutional investors. And then which
componenttext: So really nice increase in the pipeline, a couple of questions on that. First, as it relates to QS, it's definitely ramped up very quickly. Just wondering how broad-based of a demand you're seeing there for QS among institutional investors. And then which equity products right now are resonating so well with Brandywine?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: As for QS, what we're seeing is kind of threefold with them. They're continuing to build and grow their direct consultant-driven institutional business, the business that they had prior to our acquisition. We're also -- we've also been working with them s
componenttext: As for QS, what we're seeing is kind of threefold with them. They're continuing to build and grow their direct consultant-driven institutional business, the business that they had prior to our acquisition. We're also -- we've also been working with them sort of on a number of retail fronts, as we've talked about, to get them on platforms and to be able to begin to accrue ongoing kind of consistent flows. We're seeing that happen. That's slow. Those are not takeover wins. Those are just positionings that allow for you to get flows over time. And then through the insurance sub-advised space, that's really where we've had pretty quick success with them in terms of -- in some cases, topping up existing strategies, frankly, that came from our old Batterymarch platform. But the larger takeover wins really are more aligned with multi-asset class-type allocation strategies. And we just see continued demand for that. Their pipeline of interest and activity is very, very strong. We are, as I think I mentioned in my remarks, we've also got a significant pipeline of product development. They've got 9 different products right now in the pipeline looking to come forward. So that's really a reflection of the interest in the highly customized multi-asset class, multiple allocation strategies that they do. As for Brandywine, it's just -- it's a breadth of very high-quality traditional products. They've got some good large-cap products as well as some good, more -- what am I trying to say? Next-generation products and things like that. It's just -- it's nothing particularly unique. It's just good quality kind of traditional products, frankly, more classic generation or classic strategy products that are performing very well.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Carrier from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

I think you mentioned something on marketing driving that, but I just wanted to, like, get a clarification on that.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks for your question. Our typical run rate in other expenses, as I think most of you know, are more in the $50 million range. It was just a lot of different things in the mix that favorably impacted it this quarter. But we expect next quarter to bounc
componenttext: Thanks for your question. Our typical run rate in other expenses, as I think most of you know, are more in the $50 million range. It was just a lot of different things in the mix that favorably impacted it this quarter. But we expect next quarter to bounce back up to that $50 million range. We're going to have a couple of things in the quarter, both our annual director compensation that gets awarded, and we'll obviously have a few costs around the deal that we have done with RARE. We don't have any bank fees, so it's not a huge amount. But we'll definitely have some lawyers and accountants that we'll need to pay. And we're also looking at doing some incremental advertising. But $50 million run rate per quarter is the best way to think about it.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, Joe, if I think about acquisitions in the asset management space, it seems like when you look at QS, you look at Martin Currie and you look at the pace of inflows or the pipeline already, it just seems like it may be co
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, Joe, if I think about acquisitions in the asset management space, it seems like when you look at QS, you look at Martin Currie and you look at the pace of inflows or the pipeline already, it just seems like it may be coming in better than expected or faster than expected, meaning sometimes you get some dislocation or just some outflows. So just wanted to get a sense on when you look at the transactions that you've done, how are they trending relative to the expectations? And then is there something different that you guys are doing before you do these transactions that either you're already anticipating or that the clients like the demands there, that you know the route or that the flows are going to be coming in at a fairly healthy pace? It just seems like it's just been coming in at a pace that generally you'd see some weakness or dislocation as the distribution channels start to ramp up.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So great question, Mike. Look, I think a couple of things. First of all, to be candid, yes, I think we actually outperformed -- when you see a combination much as we did with QS, an acquisition -- any acquisition but then also a combination, if you recall
componenttext: So great question, Mike. Look, I think a couple of things. First of all, to be candid, yes, I think we actually outperformed -- when you see a combination much as we did with QS, an acquisition -- any acquisition but then also a combination, if you recall, we combined Batterymarch with QS. And whenever you see something like that, you expect that, that sort of gives clients an opportunity to rethink and potentially to redeem. We retained much more of the Batterymarch and QS assets through the first year of transition than we expected. So we were pleased with the retention of existing business post acquisition. We've also been, and to be perfectly candid with you, surprised at the strength of flows and business with QS. But when you step back and think about it, QS is in the sweet spot right now. Virtually every type of client that we talk to is interested in talking about and considering customized strategies. And our -- and QS's ability to be able to do that, to really be able to understand the needs of the client, and then customize a strategy either using ETFs or using some of our managers or some combination of the 2 is really quite compelling. As far as what are we doing differently or better, I just think we're doing a good job of execution. I think many -- our pipeline, our M&A pipeline is as robust as it's ever been. I think that's a function of the environment. I think it's tougher for smaller managers right now. We know that costs are rising. Fees, there's pressure on fees. So it's a tough environment for many managers. And when they look out there, the ability to join a firm to retain their investment independence, to retain their operational autonomy, to be able to tap into this Global Distribution platform, which I think QS and Martin Currie, already, their eyes are wide open with the power and strength of that platform. And then in some cases, some choose to tap into various of our other shared services to realize operational efficiency. That's a pretty good combination. And so we've just -- I think we're attracting a lot of interest right now. And I've got to give credit to our distribution teams and our product teams and all of our shared service, what we call the value chain, of Legg Mason, for really executing well and delivering. Now some of the stuff just takes time. It takes time, as Tom mentioned and I've talked about before, to get things through the pipe in terms of product creation and the regulatory hurdles and all that kind of stuff. But in the meantime, particularly as it relates to this insurance sub-advisory capability, which is really quasi-institutional, we can get moving on that pretty much right away. So I think it's we've got an attractive model. We find the right partners. It's got to be the right chemistry and the right culture. And then -- so our business model is drawing them. We have the right culture, what we believe to be the right culture going in, and then I think it's been good execution.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joe, following up on that, it seems you said your M&A pipeline is as big as it's ever been. It seems as if you have more draws on your capital today, 9 funds coming on with QS that likely needs some seed. How do we think about you prioritizing that along
componenttext: Joe, following up on that, it seems you said your M&A pipeline is as big as it's ever been. It seems as if you have more draws on your capital today, 9 funds coming on with QS that likely needs some seed. How do we think about you prioritizing that along with obviously the consistency of the buyback program that's been in place for several years now?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So look, I think -- and I'll let Pete kind of chime in here. But I think the way we think about it, Dan, is -- and this, to me, goes back to the tax shield, the fact that we generate a lot of cash. And by virtue of that tax shield, we're able to retain a
componenttext: So look, I think -- and I'll let Pete kind of chime in here. But I think the way we think about it, Dan, is -- and this, to me, goes back to the tax shield, the fact that we generate a lot of cash. And by virtue of that tax shield, we're able to retain a lot of that cash. And so we are able to do -- invest in our business. As we've done over the last year, we've been able to invest in distribution. We are able to continue to maintain a robust seed capital program for affiliates. That's one of the things, by the way, for smaller managers that are considering joining us, that seed capital program is very attractive. We are able to continue the buyback and we've been increasing our dividend. I don't want to say we can do it all forever. But I'm just saying with our tax shield and the fact that we are a big-time cash generator, and importantly, retain that cash, we feel that we're able to kind of navigate through all of this. We've done a number of acquisitions already and been able to kind of maintain a balanced capital deployment approach. Pete, am I missing anything?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, not missing anything. I might add a few things, Dan, in terms of what we've done over the last several years really since the crisis. And we've done a lot to strengthen the balance sheet, first of all. That's something we wanted to make sure we had a
componenttext: No, not missing anything. I might add a few things, Dan, in terms of what we've done over the last several years really since the crisis. And we've done a lot to strengthen the balance sheet, first of all. That's something we wanted to make sure we had a fortressed balance sheet to kind of lean back on. We've also deployed a tremendous amount of cash. So if you look at kind of where our cash was coming out of the crisis, we had a lot of money that was sitting on the balance sheet that wasn't earning much for the shareholders. So we've done some delevering. We've done some smart acquisitions and seed. And we've also returned a lot of capital to our shareholders, which we intend to continue to do even with these acquisitions that we've done. So we're continuing at that same pace, the $90 million a quarter that we've talked about.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And then just as a follow up on the RARE acquisition, I guess you cited the accretive in year one. I guess, what type of growth assumptions are kind of embedded in that? And then any numbers around the type of or level of accretion or the revenue share kind of dynamics that is in place?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: All very good questions. And we just have to be mindful a little bit of what we've talked to our counterparty about in terms of disclosure of terms, and then also what we typically do on deals this size. But basically, we've said it's going to be marginal
componenttext: All very good questions. And we just have to be mindful a little bit of what we've talked to our counterparty about in terms of disclosure of terms, and then also what we typically do on deals this size. But basically, we've said it's going to be marginally accretive for GAAP because obviously we've got now a bunch of intangibles we'll be amortizing. But it'll be many multiples of that in terms of accretive to our adjusted income. And from there, there's a bunch of information you can get from their website, et cetera. Their growth, their CAGR in terms of AUM revenues have been running higher than 20%. So we don't see any reason why that should slow down. They're in a market that has $2 trillion worth of securities that can be invested in. So they've got -- there's no constraint in terms of size. And we'd expect them to continue to grow, given normal markets. The only other thing -- and in terms of rev share, and keep in mind, we don't disclose specific rev shares for each affiliate for obvious competitive reasons. But they'll be better than what our average is. And it's negotiated within the 75% that we own, which is similar to what we said we're going to do when we leave equity on the table for management. But if you take that rev share we're getting within the 75% and look at it on a consolidated basis, it will still be slightly above where our blended average is for all of our affiliates.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think maybe, Dan -- and we can let Tom jump in maybe with a little bit of sort of market context. We do believe this is a meaningfully growing segment and that we're early in this game. Just also to help you think about this and not again to get into sp
componenttext: I think maybe, Dan -- and we can let Tom jump in maybe with a little bit of sort of market context. We do believe this is a meaningfully growing segment and that we're early in this game. Just also to help you think about this and not again to get into specifics, but this is really from a fee rate perspective something akin to our equity or global equity-type products. We're not going to get into specific fee rates. But as you think about it, it's got attractive fee rates. So fee rates consistent with what we achieve in other global equity or even U.S. equity-type products. But Tom, can you add a little bit related to kind of the larger market dimensions?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So again I think if you look, if you drill down regionally into the growth of this category, you would see 3-year growth rates well into the double digits and sometimes approaching 50% or 60%. Overall, the market is about $48 billion in existing mutu
componenttext: Yes. So again I think if you look, if you drill down regionally into the growth of this category, you would see 3-year growth rates well into the double digits and sometimes approaching 50% or 60%. Overall, the market is about $48 billion in existing mutual fund-type product. So while it has been growing, we still believe it's pretty early innings. If you look at that league table of competitors here, you see mostly specialists. And so for us, we think it's the opportunity to partner with a leader in a space that's not only growing rapidly but has a lot more room to run. In the U.S., that size of the market today is only about $16 billion and maybe half of that, $8 billion, in Europe. And as we mentioned earlier, the focus coming out of our partnership with LMGD on this will be those 2 markets. And so I can't predict future growth rates, but we think the sector is growing, we have a leader and we have the ability through the distribution team to continue to really take advantage of some of those growth rates in what are almost effectively new markets for RARE.

componenttext: My interest is piqued by the China color. Maybe you could just talk a little bit about more of that opportunity. How much more can you ramp it up in the interim? Perhaps what affiliates or other products that could be applicable? And what sort of resources are you using there in terms of distribution?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Mac. Specifically, the opportunity I mentioned with respect to China was Permal. That is a strategy that was launched in 2014 with a large Chinese financial institution with whom we enjoy a nice distribution relationship. Importantly, the fu
componenttext: Well, thanks, Mac. Specifically, the opportunity I mentioned with respect to China was Permal. That is a strategy that was launched in 2014 with a large Chinese financial institution with whom we enjoy a nice distribution relationship. Importantly, the fund that Permal manages has performed relatively well through all of the turbulence that we've seen in the China markets. And as a result, that strategy we saw, I think we mentioned about $800 million in flows into the strategy just in the last quarter. The strategy now has a total of about $1.5 billion. I would say that as it relates to sort of the attractiveness of that business, it's a lower fee rate than what their traditional institutional or retail fees would be, but they have opportunities. It's still an attractive management fee and they do have opportunities for incentive fees associated with it. As far as how it extends beyond just Permal, I mean, I can't give you what the growth rate could be, it could be significant, it could -- those flows can be a bit volatile, to be candid with you. We're excited about it. It bodes well for Permal. But those flows can be volatile, so we can't really predict what they will be. But what I'll tell you is that all of our affiliates really are in dialogue with Legg Mason, with our Global Distribution platform in terms of how can we extend this success at Permal and with this distributor into other products and into other channels in China. It's a complicated market. It's a difficult market to penetrate. We do cover it currently. We do not have a retail distribution office in China. We cover that -- or have our Hong Kong office responsible for that. But there's a lot of dialogue around how do we kind of parlay, if you will, the success that we're seeing with this distribution partner and with potential other distribution partners in China for our other affiliates. We do see opportunity there and we're excited about it.

componenttext: Well, I think you've got it spot on with the 22% typically of operating revenue. That's kind of the normal run rate for us. We merged some fund ranges offshore, and that led to some restructuring as to how we get our fees. So stuff that used to go into advisory fee to an internal entity is now treated as a distribution and servicing fee on the P&L. But it comes to us again just to a kind of internal reclass, so there's no bottom line impact at all. So is that helpful?

componenttextpreview: Yes. So thanks, Rob. Good question. So when we were looking at the ETF opportunity, we went through a little bit of a build versus buy decision looking at hiring talents, looking at properties that might be on the market for sale. Ultimately, we made the
componenttext: Yes. So thanks, Rob. Good question. So when we were looking at the ETF opportunity, we went through a little bit of a build versus buy decision looking at hiring talents, looking at properties that might be on the market for sale. Ultimately, we made the decision to build the capability in-house and brought in 2 senior professionals from Vanguard who had built the business there a number of years ago. And so for us, we can build and create something that's very specific to Legg Mason and that can help take advantage of our affiliates capabilities here at Legg. As far as operationally, the team we have is focused on product management and product strategy as well as the relationships around execution into the capital markets with the authorized participants and so forth. So we'll be leveraging service providers and custodians and vendors the way we actually do with our mutual fund platform.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just starting with the comp and benefits, a lot of ins and outs, offsets between benefits and payroll and salary and incentive. Is there a way that you could maybe just sort of either go over it or distill it for us? Because it just seems like there ar
componenttext: So just starting with the comp and benefits, a lot of ins and outs, offsets between benefits and payroll and salary and incentive. Is there a way that you could maybe just sort of either go over it or distill it for us? Because it just seems like there are unusual items that are being offset, multiple unusual items that are being offset. What's the best way to sort of think about, in fairly straightforward terms, and I can certainly circle back later if that's necessary, the increase in the comp line in the June quarter from the March quarter because there's just a lot going on there?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Eric. And there was. So I appreciate the question. So recall, we always highlight an uptick in compensation in the first 2 calendar quarters every year. But as you're talking about specifics, I can walk through that. In the March quarter, that's whe
componenttext: Sure, Eric. And there was. So I appreciate the question. So recall, we always highlight an uptick in compensation in the first 2 calendar quarters every year. But as you're talking about specifics, I can walk through that. In the March quarter, that's when we see FICA and social taxes kind of resetting as well as 401(k) matches and profit-sharing. Then in the June quarter, all of those factors continue up until the point we pay bonuses. And at that stage, our high earners all kind of get above the limits for those programs. But the other thing we had going on in the June quarter is that's also when we make our annual equity and deferred compensation awards. And as I mentioned on the call, there's some retirement eligibility. When people get within 4 years of our normal retirement age, which is 62, GAAP accounting requires you to kind of short -- even though the vesting period is still 4 years, people can vest after they have hypothetically retired, so long as their good levers don't compete, don't solicit. But the accounting rules changed a number of years ago on that, that if you're, say, 59, you've now got a 3-year service period, even though legally there, it's a 4-year period. So that had an impact in the quarter of about $0.05 this year and it had about a $0.02 impact last year. So we have it every year. It was just a little bit elevated this year. We had a few high earners that hit it. But it's basically just accounting noise. It's accelerating the expense we take anyway. And it's basically no impact in terms of cash comp -- or no impact to our cash bottom line earnings. And I think probably the most important thing for everyone on the call is we expect next quarter to drop back to the 53%, 54% that we've been guiding to. And blended average by the time we get to the end of the year will be right in that 53%, 54% based on our current projections. Does that -- so I know it was a bit cloudy. Does that help?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it definitely does help. And I'll circle back with Alan to even deepen my understanding further. But this has definitely moved me along. One more for Joe. I was intrigued by your comment about some fundamental sort of drawbacks to fixed income indexes
componenttext: No, it definitely does help. And I'll circle back with Alan to even deepen my understanding further. But this has definitely moved me along. One more for Joe. I was intrigued by your comment about some fundamental sort of drawbacks to fixed income indexes. And I just wanted to sort sharpen my understanding of that. Could you sort of build on your comments? What is  it about fixed income indexes that somehow either doesn't capture your strength or makes them deficient?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, look, first of all, they capture probably -- they're market weight  -- first of all, they're market-weighted, much like the equity indexes. So the biggest issuers tend to be -- have the highest percentage capture in the index itself. In the broader
componenttext: Well, look, first of all, they capture probably -- they're market weight  -- first of all, they're market-weighted, much like the equity indexes. So the biggest issuers tend to be -- have the highest percentage capture in the index itself. In the broader kind of the Barclays agg, which everybody uses and is the kind of the main benchmark index, I think it's only 35% -- of the eligible securities in fixed income, only 35% are captured within that index. So that tells you that there's a whole world out there, 2/3 -- 2x as many securities and asset classes within fixed income that can be used, and in fact, active managers do use to kind of position their portfolio for different types of market environments. As you can imagine, given what's happened with the U.S. government over the last -- really since the crisis, the massive increase that we've seen in government issuance, treasuries are included in that index. So consequently, given that it's a market cap-weighted index, the U.S. Treasury component of it has been significantly -- has significantly increased. So that really allows for active managers who have the flexibility to go beyond that 35% of available products and strategies in fixed income to outperform governments. And spread products and credit products and unconstrained types of securities have the potential to significantly outperform treasuries. So the index itself is now much more Treasury or U.S. government security-related than it was even before the crisis because of the massive issuance of the government. The fact that -- look, it's different certainly in equities, but on the fixed income side, roughly 70% of all active fixed income managers beat the benchmark. Some of them, like us, like Brandywine and Western, beat it big time. But even the kind of average, median fixed income manager can beat the index. It's just not that hard. So for people who actually go into the index, we think they're making a choice to underperform over time, or at least underperform their opportunity, for sure.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. But just in light of the majority interest stake in RARE, can you just give us an update on where you stand with the management equity plans? I know each affiliate is different, but I think it's been a wh
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. But just in light of the majority interest stake in RARE, can you just give us an update on where you stand with the management equity plans? I know each affiliate is different, but I think it's been a while since you put one in place. So just wondering if you could give us some color on where you stand on that front and any implications for margins over time.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael. Yes, I think we've said that we were disappointed that it's been so long since we've completed one. That's just a function of a lot going on here, and as you pointed out, sort of the complexity associated with them, whether it be structur
componenttext: Thanks, Michael. Yes, I think we've said that we were disappointed that it's been so long since we've completed one. That's just a function of a lot going on here, and as you pointed out, sort of the complexity associated with them, whether it be structuring or tax, and particularly, with those entities that are multijurisdictional. So that's what always sort of becomes -- slows things down. It just takes time. That said, I fully expect that over the course of this fiscal year, we're going to complete some, whether that's 1 or 2 or 3. I think right now, we sort of have 3 that we're working on. And I would expect certainly one of those, if not more, to get done for us. And as you know, with those, we expect to incorporate, as part of that, a tiering of rev shares. So we're very anxious to do -- to complete these with the affiliates. The affiliates are very anxious generally and our Board is very supportive and anxious. So we're continuing our focus there and I expect that we'll get at least one done, if not more, in this fiscal year.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: And Michael, as it relates to the margin impact of those, just keep in mind that they're relatively muted because it's effectively a call option going forward. There's not a big GAAP charge upfront. And then the tiered rev shares, as Joe refers to, actually have the opportunity to improve the margin as we go forward.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As I've done on the last few calls, I'd just like to share what I believe to be are the 5 key takeaways for this past quarter. First of all, another quarter of organic growth, our fifth straight quarter of positive net flows, again, against a f
componenttext:
Thank you. As I've done on the last few calls, I'd just like to share what I believe to be are the 5 key takeaways for this past quarter. First of all, another quarter of organic growth, our fifth straight quarter of positive net flows, again, against a fairly challenging market backdrop. Secondly, opportunities for continued growth remain, with our unfunded pipeline win strong across affiliates and progress within our Global Distribution platform continuing. Thirdly, we are well positioned to capture share in a rising rate environment and we welcome a return to rate normalization. Fourth, we continue to diversify our lineup of client offerings through a robust product development pipeline, a robust M&A pipeline and now the acquisition of RARE Infrastructure. And lastly, our focus on prudent strategic business investment while actively returning capital to shareholders via share repurchase and dividends will continue.
These 5 key takeaways speak to executing on a plan that we've shared with you for some time now. We intend to continue to deliver on that plan. So I'd like to thank you for your continued interest in and confidence in Legg Mason. And I look forward to updating you on our continued progress next quarter. Thank you.
